They are also for many observers strongly sensual, their lush colors, full, curving contours, overall sense of opulence, and implied perfumed scent of the flowers suggestive, perhaps, of female nudes languidly reclining on luxurious couches."
== References == * [http://www.nga.gov/fcgi-bin/tinfo_f?object=93464 NGA: ''Giant Magnolias on a Blue Velvet Cloth'']
[[Category:Paintings by Martin Johnson Heade]] [[Category:1890 paintings]] [[Category:Collections of the National Gallery of Art]] [[Category:Still life paintings]] [[Category:Flower paintings]]

A list of theater terms, and brief descriptions, listed in alphabetical order.
*'''Act''': A division of a play, may be further broken down into "scenes". Also, what the performers do on-stage.<ref name=Laguna>{{cite web | url=http://www.lagunaplayhouse.com/downloads/GLOSSARYOFTHEATRETERMS.pdf | publisher=Laguna Playhouse | title=Glossary of Theatre Terms | accessdate=February 23, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130328120515/http://www.lagunaplayhouse.com/downloads/GLOSSARYOFTHEATRETERMS.pdf | archivedate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> * '''[[Ad libitum|Ad-lib]]''': When a performer improvises line on-stage. Derived from ''ad libitum'' (Latin).<ref name=Laguna /> * '''Aisle''': An open space amongst seating for passage.<ref name=TCA>{{cite web | url=http://www.theatrecrafts.com/glossary/results.php?searchtype=2&wordsearch=A&submit3=Search | publisher=theatrecrafts | title=Search results starting with A | accessdate=February 23, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223150312/http://www.theatrecrafts.com/glossary/results.php?searchtype=2&wordsearch=A&submit3=Search | archivedate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> * '''Alternate''': see Understudy. * '''[[Amphitheatre|Amphitheater]]''': an open-air theater, with seats rising in curved rows.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/amphitheater | publisher=Merriam-Webster | title=Amphitheater | accessdate=February 23, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826013108/http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/amphitheater | archivedate=August 26, 2014}}</ref> * '''[[Angel investor|Angel]]''': An individual or organization which provides financial support for a production.<ref name=TCA /> * '''[[Apron stage|Apron]]''': The front area of the stage, nearest the audience; the portion of the stage in front of proscenium arch.<ref name=TCA /> * '''[[Aside]]''': A line spoken by an actor/actress directly to the audience, unheard by the other performers on-stage.<ref name=TCA /> * '''[[Assistant director]]''': Works very closely with the director and with the cast. They will gather research on the production, help keep the production true to the director's vision and help lead rehearsals should the director not be able to attend. * '''[[Stage management#Assistant stage manager|Assistant stage manager]]''': Assists the production stage manager, with everything from taping floor plan marking to making sure that everyone has a copy of the script. They also make sure that the set has the needed props. Before a rehearsal the assistant stage manager helps the stage manager make sure everything is ready. At the end of rehearsal the assistant stage manager along with the stage manager will make sure that the space is locked up. Often shortened to '''ASM'''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://theatre.uoregon.edu/assistant-stage-manager/ | publisher=University of Oregon | title=Assistant Stage Manager | accessdate=February 23, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223144649/http://theatre.uoregon.edu/assistant-stage-manager/ | archivedate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> * '''[[Audition]]''': The activity where actors/actresses perform for the director or casting director, in order to obtain roles in a production.<ref name=Capa>{{cite web | url=http://capa.com/files/about/education-/theatreterms.pdf | title=The Theatre Dictionary | accessdate=February 23, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121175925/http://www.capa.com/files/about/education-/theatreterms.pdf | archivedate=January 21, 2013}}</ref> * '''[[Auditorium]]''': The portion of a theater which contains the audience seating.<ref name=TCA /> * '''[[Avante Garde]]''': Experimental or innovative works or people, derived from the French.<ref name=TCA /> * '''[[Balcony]]''': An elevated portion of seating in the back of the auditorium.<ref name=Laguna /> * '''[[Curtain call|Curtain Call]]''': At the end of a live performance the cast will come out and do a bow while the audience applauds.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-curtain-call.htm | publisher=Wise Geek | title=What is a curtain call? | accessdate=February 23, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140723073418/http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-curtain-call.htm | archivedate=July 23, 2014}}</ref> *'''Doubling''': When an actor plays more than one character in a production. Most times this is done for economical reasons but it can be that because an actor would like to take on more than one role in the performance. *'''[[Understudy]]''': A person who learns the part of a specific character or characters. Should the performer who is cast in those roles be unable to perform their part due for any reason (e.g. illness, injury etc.), the understudy will step in and perform the role. Also known as an '''Alternate'''.<ref name=Capa />
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Glossaries of the arts]]

revision.comment: Add: year, pages, issue, volume, journal, title, author pars. 1-1. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]].
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{BLP primary sources|date=August 2015}} {{BLP sources|date=August 2015}} {{Third-party|date=August 2015}} {{Orphan|date=April 2016}} }}
'''Julie McNamara''' (born 26 March 1960) is a theatre director, playwright, producer, actor and poet. She is Artistic Director of touring theatre company Vital Xposure. Patron of disability arts organisation [[DaDaFest]] and a political activist for human rights and gender politics.
==Early career== McNamara first performed as a backing singer in 1977 with punk band [[The Plague]]. That same year she was voted Actress of the Year in Merseyside Drama Festival.<ref name="nostringsattached1">{{cite web|url=http://www.nostringsattached.org.au/julie-mcnamara.html |title=Julie McNamara | No Strings Attached Theatre of Disability |publisher=Nostringsattached.org.au |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
She went on to work with Lowbrow Theatre, and the [[National Student Drama Festival]] at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]]. She wrote and directed a trilogy: Venus and the Fly Trap, Cock and Bull Stories and Kill the Fatted Calf all produced in Nottingham 1981- 2.<ref name="nostringsattached1"/> By 1987 she was working for socio-political company Banner Theatre touring the UK’s Trade Union clubs, factory floors and picket lines.<ref name="nostringsattached1"/>
==Theatre and disability== The majority of McNamara’s work is created to ensure access for Deaf and disabled people is aesthetically integrated within the performance. However, she feels this has not always been successful and there is still scope for new developments. In a 2010 interview with Disability Arts Online she clarified: “We still didn't get it right for everybody. Some people don't read [[British Sign Language]], their first language may be English and we had requests for 'Stage text' which frankly I hate. I don't know what the solution is. I still need to explore possibilities, but I am more and more convinced that the 'access' should never get in the way of the aesthetics of the craft.” <ref name="disabilityartsonline1">{{cite web|url=http://www.disabilityartsonline.org.uk/animate_talks_julie-mcNamara |title=Interview: Julie McNamara discusses her theatre practice, part of Shape Animate |publisher=disability arts online |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
==Theatre== Pig Tales, 2002. McNamara gained a commission through [[Ovalhouse]] and [[Jacksons Lane]] for the Xposure Festival of Disability Arts. She teamed up with Jessica Higgs, Director of In Tandem theatre company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jessicahiggs.org/biography/ |title=Biography |publisher=Jessica Higgs |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> Pig Tales is composed of five short vignettes based on the nursery rhyme ‘This little piggy went to market’. Pig, the central character, is a female child raised as a boy. Pig’s warring Liverpool Irish family are haunted by the rigid teachings of the Catholic church. Disappointed with their peers and dislocated from their roots, the family implodes. Pig reflects on the chaos and confusion of an adolescence set against the brutality of the Mental Health System.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.ovalhouse.com/whatson/detail/pig_tales |title=Pig Tales |publisher=Ovalhouse |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.catalystmedia.org.uk/issues/catalyst2/pig_tales.htm |title=Catalyst Articles - Issue 2 |publisher=Catalystmedia.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304134643/http://www.catalystmedia.org.uk/issues/catalyst2/pig_tales.htm |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The production was chosen as 'Critics Choice' in [[The Times]], touring both nationally and internationally.<ref name="nostringsattached1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.shapearts.org.uk/FAQs/2005 |title=FAQ | 2005 |publisher=Shape Arts |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.juliemc.com/pigtalesgallery.html |title=Pig Tales Gallery |publisher=Juliemc.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
Pig’s Sister, also written and performed by McNamara and directed by Jessica Higgs, was created in association with [[Theatre Workshop Scotland]], launched at [[The Poor School]] in London before transferring to [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottisharts.org.uk/1/artsinscotland/drama/projects/archive/degenerate3.aspx |title=Scottish Arts Council - Archive - Degenerate 3 |publisher=Scottisharts.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> Julie McNamara went on to direct the play herself, casting two men in the roles of Pig and Sissy. Pig was played by Adrian Wilkes and Sissy by Michael McNamara for DaDa Festival, Liverpool 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dadafest.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/DaDaFest-2006-Programme.pdf |format=PDF |title=DaDaFest 2006 |publisher=Dadafest.co.uk |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
Steak and Chelsea Out to Lunch, was first commissioned by No Strings Attached Theatre in partnership with [[Feast Festival]] Adelaide (2008) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disabilityartsonline.org.uk/High-McNamara-Steak-and-Chelsea-Out-to-Lunch |title=Review: Rachel High and Julie McNamara star in Steak and Chelsea Out to Lunch |publisher=disability arts online |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
Crossings (2008 -2010) was first commissioned by DaDa Festival in 2008. Originally directed by [[Karena Johnson]], it was re-directed by [[Paulette Randall]] and toured extensively throughout UK, closing at the [[Grand Opera House, Belfast]]. The production was featured on Ulster television [[UTV (TV channel)|UTV]], [[BBC Radio 4]] and attracted a Writer's Award through [[DaDaFest]] and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]].<ref name="nostringsattached1"/> McNamara gained the South Bank Show Award for diversity (2010) <ref name="disabilityartsonline1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.juliemc.com/raving.html |title=Julie McNamara- Raving Reviews |publisher=Juliemc.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2759712/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t146|title=Julie McNamara|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
The Knitting Circle (2010 - 2013) Directed first by Antoinette Lester <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thealbany.org.uk/event_detail/930/Theatre/The-Knitting-Circle |title=Theatre | The Knitting Circle |publisher=The Albany |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> and then by [[Paulette Randall]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disabilityartsonline.org.uk/The-Knitting-Circle |title=Profile: The Knitting Circle by Julie McNamara |publisher=disability arts online |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> It was written from authentic survivor testimony. The production painted a picture of the lives of women who lived in the old asylums of Britain's long care system. Set within a fictional institution in the 1980s called Harper Park, the patients face the worst aspects of [[Margaret Thatcher]]'s 'Community Care' or [[care in the community]] scheme in the 1980s. The idea for the production was inspired by an old recording made 30 years ago, when McNamara was working as a nursing assistant in a long-stay hospital in the Hertfordshire. The cassette contained the voices of female patients she had lived and worked with, all telling their personal stories.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-ouch-22484308 |title=The secret asylum knitting club - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
Whisper Me Happy Ever After (2014) Inclusive theatre company Face Front commissioned McNamara to write Whisper Me Happy Ever After. The play is written from the testimonies of children between 9 – 12 years who have lived with violence in the home. The play makes a strong call out for new ways of dealing with domestic violence and ways to reach young people affected. The story is developed through research with young people and parents who've survived domestic or gang violence, and with teachers, mental health experts, the police, domestic violence forums and support groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facefront.org/index.php/theatre-in-education/list-of-tisp/reducing-crime-and-domestic-violence/151-whisper-me-happy-ever-after |title=Whisper Me Happy Ever After |publisher=Facefront.org |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
Let Me Stay (2013-2015) McNamara wrote Let Me Stay as a tribute to her mother Shirley, who lives with [[Alzheimer's]]. The play is the result of years of recordings and filming her mother’s stories and songs. Shirley McNamara collaborated throughout the creative process. The message of this play is "it is possible to live well with Dementia". McNamara performed in this one woman show under the direction of [[Paulette Randall]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://albanydeptford.wordpress.com/2014/06/16/julie-mcnamara-and-director-paulette-randall-discuss-let-me-stay/ |title=Julie McNamara and director Paulette Randall discuss Let Me Stay | The Albany, Deptford |publisher=Albanydeptford.wordpress.com |date=2014-06-16 |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> Let Me Stay launched in October 2013 at Interacting Festival Corban Arts Centre, Auckland. Between 2014 and 2015 the play toured UK, Scotland, Northern Ireland and NE Brazil, closing on 20 June 2015 at Downpatrick, NI.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://theweereview.com/preview/preview-smhaff-2014/ |title=Preview: SMHAFF 2014 |publisher=The Wee Review |date=2014-09-29 |accessdate=2017-04-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://transform.britishcouncil.org.br/pt-br/content/julie-mcnamara-no-21o-janeiro-de-grandes-espetaculos |title=Julie McNamara no 21º Janeiro de Grandes Espetáculos | Transform |publisher=Transform.britishcouncil.org.br |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11 |language=pt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150524045411/http://transform.britishcouncil.org.br/pt-br/content/julie-mcnamara-no-21o-janeiro-de-grandes-espetaculos |archivedate=24 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://artsaccess.com.au/2013/09/the-art-of-inclusive-arts-and-scriptwriting-workshops-with-julie-mcnamara/ |title=The Art of Inclusive Arts with Julie McNamara « Arts Access Victoria |publisher=Artsaccess.com.au |date=2013-09-25 |accessdate=2015-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150331055332/http://artsaccess.com.au/2013/09/the-art-of-inclusive-arts-and-scriptwriting-workshops-with-julie-mcnamara/ |archivedate=31 March 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.compreingressos.com/espetaculos/3830-Let-Me-Stay-de-Julie-McNamara-%0D%0A%28Deixe-me-Ficar-de-Julie-McNamara%29 |title=Let Me Stay de Julie McNamara (Deixe-me Ficar de Julie McNamara) |publisher=Compreingressos.Com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> The tour was supported with an award by Unlimited.<ref name="weareunlimited1">{{cite web|url=http://weareunlimited.org.uk/commission/vital-xposure/ |title=Vital Xposure - Unlimited |publisher=Weareunlimited.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
The Disappearance of Dorothy Lawrence written by McNamara and directed by [[Paulette Randall]] opened on 11 September 2015 at [[Arena Theatre, Wolverhampton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wlv.ticketsolve.com/shows/873537901/events?show_id=873537901 |title=The Disappearance of Dorothy Lawrence - wlv |publisher=Wlv.ticketsolve.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> The play was based on the life of historical character [[Dorothy Lawrence]]. Her extraordinary story highlights the silencing of women’s voices throughout history and the connection with the mental health system as a tool of censorship and repression. [[Paulette Randall]] directs the play which involves a cast of four and includes integrated subtitling, [[British Sign Language]] interpretation and [[Audio description]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pleasance.co.uk/event/disappearance-dorothy-lawrence/performances |title=The Disappearance of Dorothy Lawrence - performances | Pleasance Theatre Trust |publisher=Pleasance.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.ipswich-waterfront.co.uk/ai1ec-event/vital-exposure-presents-the-disappearance-of-dorothy-lawrence/|title=Vital Exposure presents THE DISAPPEARANCE OF DOROTHY LAWRENCE | Ipswich Town and Ipswich Waterfront|publisher=Ipswich-waterfront.co.uk|date=|accessdate=2015-08-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924040016/http://www.ipswich-waterfront.co.uk/ai1ec-event/vital-exposure-presents-the-disappearance-of-dorothy-lawrence/|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In June 2015 Julie McNamara was commissioned to respond to the collections of medical museums as part of the project [http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/museumstudies/rcmg/projects/exceptional-an Exceptional and Extraordinary: unruly bodies and minds in the medical museum]. Other artists commissioned were [[Francesca Martinez]], David Havey and Deaf Men Dancing. McNamara's piece was entitled Hold the Hearse!<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(16)30694-8 |title=Exceptional and extraordinary artists |journal=The Lancet |volume=387 |issue=10035 |pages=2282 |year=2016 |last1=Moore |first1=Wendy }}</ref><ref>http://www.bigissuenorth.com/2016/06/blog-julie-mcnamara-hold-the-hearse/18996</ref>
==Film== McNamara was Artistic Director of London Disability Arts Forum from 1998, she worked with London Disability Arts Forum and Caglar Kimyoncu to create the Disability Film Festival at South Bank’s National Film Theatre, now [[British Film Institute|BFI]]. The festival closed in 2006 but the creative team returned to the National Film Theatre for a fresh collaboration as part of Liberty Festival in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://whatson.bfi.org.uk/Online/default.asp?doWork::WScontent::loadArticle=Load&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::article_id=558E4739-55DC-4690-A979-E1970775B549&sessionlanguage=&SessionSecurity::linkName= |title=Liberty 2012: Disability Film |publisher=Whatson.bfi.org.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
After leaving London Disability Arts Forum in 2006, McNamara was awarded the DaDa Festival’s Lifetime Achievement Award for services to Disability Arts.<ref name="nostringsattached1"/>
Her film credits include playing the part of Sam in the feature film Stud Life (2012). The IMDB also lists her film contribution as performing herself in Vicky! (1992) and the Southbank Show (2009).
==Writer== McNamara writing work includes all of the plays afore mentioned. She also had poetry published in several anthologies by Survivors' Press,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.survivorspoetry.org/the-poetry/publications/poetry-express/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123152753/http://www.survivorspoetry.org/the-poetry/publications/poetry-express/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-11-23 |title=Poetry Express |publisher=Survivorspoetry.org |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2015-08-11 }}</ref> Bloodaxe Books,<ref>{{cite web|author=Simon Rogers |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2011/mar/30/arts-council-funding-decisions-list |title=Arts council funding: get the full decisions list | data and visualisation | Culture |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> and Karnac Books.<ref name="google2006">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6HZjGkJTG4gC&pg=PR11&lpg=PR11&dq=Lifetime%27s+Achievement+Award+2006+Julie+McNamara&source=bl&ots=YB3bslIoIY&sig=CZnfMHvr8fKdTENTjRRkyKcwB1w&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDAQ6AEwA2oVChMIkarTjYuhxwIVQc9yCh2TRg0E#v=onepage&q=Lifetime's%20Achievement%20Award%202006%20Julie%20McNamara&f=false |title=Telling Stories?: Attachment-based Approaches to the Treatment of Psychosis - Sarah Benamer |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebay.ca/itm/NEW-Telling-Stories-Attachment-Based-Approach-to-the-Treatment-of-Psychosis-by-/131502747163?hash=item1e9e2cae1b |title=NEW Telling Stories Attachment Based Approach TO THE Treatment OF Psychosis BY 185575875X | eBay |publisher=Ebay.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> Her first collection, edited by Joe Bidder and Hilary Porter: Chaos Calls was published in 2012 by Vital Xposure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disabilityartsonline.org.uk/julie-mcnamara-chaos-calls |title=Poetry: Julie McNamara: Chaos Calls |publisher=disability arts online |date=2014-05-17 |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
==Singer== Recordings of McNamara’s singing kept at the British Library: The lords and ladies of Little Egypt 1988 and “I was born in A MerseyTown”(first line) as part of the Traditional Music in England project, John Howson collection,1992 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://sounds.bl.uk/World-and-traditional-music/John-Howson-Collection |title=John Howson English, Irish and Scottish Folk Music Collection - World and traditional music | British Library |publisher=Sounds |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
==UK Awards== Actress of the Year 1977, Merseyside Drama Festival (Liverpool) <ref name="nostringsattached1"/> Theatre People Award 2003, Arts Council England (London) <ref name="theatrebrum1">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.theatrebrum.com/tag/uncategorized/ |title=Uncategorized |publisher=Theatre Brum |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> Emerging Artist Award 2004-2006, Arts Council England (London) <ref name="theatrebrum1"/> Lifetime's Achievement Award 2006, Liverpool DaDa Festival <ref name="google2006"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artinliverpool.com/culturearch/annual_events/dadafest/ |title=Liverpool Culture Blog: DaDaFest Archives |publisher=Artinliverpool.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> DaDa festival writer award 2009 with ITV Productions <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adiarts.ie/whats-on/new-theatre-piece-by-julie-mcnamara-crossings-at-grand-opera-house-belfast-9th-10th-11th-february |title=Arts & Disability Ireland / Whats On / New Theatre Piece by Julie McNamara: 'Crossings' at Grand Opera House, Belfast 9th / 10th / 11th February |publisher=Adiarts.ie |date= |accessdate=2015-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061241/http://www.adiarts.ie/whats-on/new-theatre-piece-by-julie-mcnamara-crossings-at-grand-opera-house-belfast-9th-10th-11th-february |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Southbank Show Diversity Award 2010 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist//ITVProgs/2010/01/31/153990005001/?s=south+bank+show |title=SOUTH BANK SHOW AWARDS (SOUTH BANK SHOW AWARDS (2010)) |publisher=Itnsource.com |date=2010-01-31 |accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> Unlimited Award 2014 <ref name="weareunlimited1"/>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{Authority control}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:McNamara, Julie}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American theatre directors]] [[Category:20th-century American dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Actors with disabilities]]

page.title: List of film and television accidents

revision.comment: v2.0 - Repaired 1 link to disambiguation page - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[Red Heat]] / [[WP:WCW]] project (Link equal to linktext)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} This is intended to be a list of notable accidents that occurred during the shooting of films and television, such as cast or crew fatalities or serious accidents that plagued production. It is not intended to be a list of every minor injury an actor or stuntman suffered during filming. Stuntwork accounts for over half of all film-related injuries, with an average of five deaths for every 2,000 injuries.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} From 1980 to 1990, there were 37 deaths relating to accidents during stunts; 24 of these deaths involved the use of helicopters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uic.edu/sph/glakes/harts1/HARTS_library/stunts.txt|title= Stunt Safety By Michael McCann, Ph.D., C.I.H.}}</ref>
==1910s== * ''Across the Border'' (1914). On July 1, 1914, while on location in [[Canon City, Colorado]], cast member Grace McHugh was filming a scene where her character was crossing the [[Arkansas River]] in a boat. When the boat capsized, camera operator Owen Carter immediately jumped into the river to save her. He dragged her onto a [[sandbar]] that was actually [[quicksand]]. The rest of the film crew watched helplessly as they were sucked into the quicksand and drowned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=CTR19140702.2.5|title=Grace McHugh, Golden Girl, Is Drowned|author=Staff|work=([[Golden, Colorado|Golden]]) [[Golden Transcript|Colorado Transcript]]|page=1|date=July 2, 1915|accessdate=September 7, 2016}}</ref> *''[[The Birth of a Nation]]'' (1915). Future film director [[Erich von Stroheim]] fell off a roof and broke two ribs in one scene as an extra.{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} *[[The Girl of the Golden West (1915 film)|''The Girl of the Golden West'']] (1915). Actor [[House Peters Sr.]] suffered serious burns to his face and hands when a prop pistol exploded upon being fired.<ref>Katchmer, George A. ''Eighty Silent Film Stars: Biographies and Filmographies of the Obscure to the Well Known.'' Jefferson, NC: McFarland, 1991. p-785.</ref> *[[The Captive (1915 film)|''The Captive'']] (1915). During filming of a scene where soldiers were required to break down a locked door, the extras fired at the door using live ammunition to give the scene more realism. The director then ordered the extras to reload with blanks in order to film the next shot in which the door is broken down. But one of the extras inadvertently left a live round in his rifle which discharged, shooting another extra, Charles Chandler, in the head, killing him instantly.<ref>DeMille, Cecil B., and Donald Hayne, ed. ''The Autobiography of Cecil B. DeMille''. London: W.H. Allen, 1960. p-116-117.</ref> *''[[The Woman God Forgot]]'' (1917). In one scene, extras were required to be thrown over the side of an Aztec pyramid. The 'pyramid' was built of wood and covered in paper on which sand had been glued to create the appearance of stone. The extras were 'sand-papered' as they slid down the side of the structure. Having expected such injuries, a crew member was waiting at the bottom with a bucket of iodine.<ref>Fountain, Leatrice G., and John R. Maxim ''1985: Dark Star''. London: Sidgwick & Jackson. p-189.</ref> * ''[[The Valley of the Giants (1919 film)|The Valley of the Giants]]'' (1919). Silent era star [[Wallace Reid]] was badly injured in a train crash during filming in Oregon. His injuries caused him severe pain and the studio supplied him with increasing quantities of morphine so he could keep working. Addicted to morphine and also suffering from alcoholism, Reid died in 1923 at the age of 32.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goldensilents.com/stars/wallacereid.html |title=Wallace Reid (1891-1923) |publisher=''Golden Silents'' |accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> *Unidentified [[Henry Lehrman]] Comedy (1919): Comedian [[Billie Ritchie]], while working on a short comedy film, was kicked in the stomach by an [[ostrich]] and sustained internal injuries.<ref>[http://www.bearmanormedia.com/index.php?route=product/product&filter_name=massa&product_id=638 Steve Massa- Lame Brains and Lunatics pp. 66-67]</ref>
==1920s== * ''[[Haunted Spooks]]'' (1920). On the set of a publicity shoot that took place while filming, actor and comedian [[Harold Lloyd]] picked up what he thought was a prop bomb with the fuse lit but realized too late the bomb was real. It detonated, blowing off the thumb and first finger of his right hand and also temporarily blinding him. For the rest of his career, Lloyd concealed his missing fingers with a prosthetic glove.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.silentfilm.org/archive/girl-shy-1924 |title=''Girl Shy'', 1924 |publisher=San Francisco Silent Film Festival |accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[The Skywayman]]'' (1920). Pilots Milton Elliott and [[Ormer Locklear]] were killed on 2 August 1920, during filming. Their plane crashed at the DeMille Airfield, along Wilshire Blvd. in Los Angeles, while filming night scenes.<ref name="Farmer1984">{{cite book|last=Farmer|first=James H.|title=Broken wings: Hollywood's air crashes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vAMIAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 May 2012|year=1984|publisher=Pictorial Histories Pub. Co.|isbn=978-0-933126-46-6|page=108}}</ref> *[[Manslaughter (1922 film)|''Manslaughter'']] (1922). Stunt man Leo Noomis was required to crash a police motorcycle into the side of a car at 45 miles per hour. Noomis suffered six broken ribs and a fractured pelvis while performing the stunt.<ref>Wise, Arthur, and Derek Ware. ''Stunting in the Cinema''. London: Constable, 1973. p-43.</ref> * ''[[Souls for Sale]]'' (1923). Actress [[Barbara La Marr]] injured her ankle during filming and doctors prescribed not only morphine but also cocaine to control the pain and enable her to continue filming. Working on the production left La Marr addicted to drugs, a factor that contributed to her premature death three years later.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://barbaralamarr.com/Page_2.html |title=Barbara La Marr Biography |author=Lore, Anne |accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Sherlock, Jr.]]'' (1924). While hanging from a water tower, [[Buster Keaton]] pulled a rope that released water from the tower, knocking him to the ground. In the scene, he stood and ran into the distance. During a routine physical examination 11 years later, an X-ray revealed that Keaton's neck had been fractured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.silentfilm.org/pages/detail/3691|title=Sherlock Jr., 1924|work=Silent Film Festival|last=Johansson|first=David|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref> *''[[The Warrens of Virginia (1924 film)|The Warrens of Virginia]]'' (1924). On 29 November 1923, while working on location in [[San Antonio, Texas]], [[Martha Mansfield]] was severely burned when a match, tossed by a cast member, ignited her [[American Civil War|Civil War]] costume of [[Hoop skirt|hoopskirts]] and flimsy ruffles. Mansfield was playing the role of Agatha Warren and had just finished her scenes and retired to a car when her clothing burst into flames. Her neck and face were saved when leading man Wilfred Lytell threw his heavy [[overcoat]] over her. The [[chauffeur]] of Mansfield's car was burned badly on his hands while trying to remove the burning clothing from the actress. The fire was put out, but she sustained substantial burns to her body and died the following day.<ref>''[[New York Times]]'', "Martha Mansfield, Film Star, Dies of Burns Caused by Costume Fired by Smoker's Match", 1 December 1923, Page 1.</ref> *''[[Ben-Hur (1925 film)|Ben-Hur]]'' (1925). An early filming attempt of the chariot race was done on location at the [[Circus Maximus]] in Rome. It brought about the death of one stuntman when a wheel of his chariot broke.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Parade's Gone By...|last=Brownlow|first=Kevin|authorlink=Kevin Brownlow|year=1969}} quoted in {{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/movies/films/benhur.asp|title=Ben-Hur|work=snopes.com|last=Johnson|first=Judy|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref> * [[The General (1926 film)|''The General'']] (1926). During filming of the epic comedy in Oregon, there were a number of incidents. Several National Guardsmen, employed as extras for the Civil War battle scenes, were injured by mishaps caused by misfired muskets or explosions. Director and star Buster Keaton was knocked unconscious when he stood too close to a cannon firing. Assistant director Harry Barnes was accidentally hit in the face by a blank charge. Train brakeman Fred Lowry sued the production for US$2,900 after his foot was crushed when it was run over by a locomotive wheel during filming of one of the railway scenes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.angelfire.com/indie/busterkeaton/Filming.html |title=The Filming of ''The General'' |publisher=Angelfire.com |accessdate=19 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Wings (1927 film)|Wings]]'' (1927). During filming of the World War I aerial combat scenes, stunt pilot [[Dick Grace]] was required to deliberately crash-land a [[Fokker D-VII]], specially modified to "crumple" on impact. When the Fokker struck the ground, the landing gear failed to crumple, making the impact a heavier one than planned. This caused Grace's safety straps to break, sending his head through the instrument panel, leaving him with four crushed vertebrae and a broken neck. Amazingly, Grace spent only six weeks in the hospital and was back performing stunt work within a year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.silentsaregolden.com/articles/aviationstuntmen.html |title=Daredevils in the Air: Three of the Greats – Wilson, Locklear and Grace |author=Lussier, Tim |publisher=''Silents Are Golden'' |date=2004 |accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[Noah's Ark (1928 film)|Noah's Ark]]'' (1928). Three people died, one man lost a leg and a number were injured in a scene where several hundred extras were caught in the "[[Genesis flood narrative|Great Flood]]." The deaths were instrumental in the introduction of film safety regulations the following year.<ref>{{cite book |author=Baxter, John O. |title=Stunt; the story of the great movie stunt men |publisher=Doubleday |location=Garden City, N.Y |year=1974 |pages= |isbn=0-385-06520-5}}</ref> * [[The Aviator (1929 film)|''The Aviator'']] (1929). During aerial scouting for locations, an aircraft crashed, killing cameraman Alvin Knechtel and actor and stunt pilot [[William Hauber]].<ref name="Yahoo">{{cite web |url=https://tv.yahoo.com/news/safety-set-camera-crew-outnumber-stunt-personnel-4-165559917.html |title=Safety On Set: Camera Crew Outnumber Stunt Personnel 4-To-1 In On-Set Deaths |author=Robb, David |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] |date=8 April 2014 |accessdate=19 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[The Godless Girl]]'' (1929). The filming of one scene required cast members [[Lina Basquette]] and [[George Duryea]] to be trapped in a burning building and both actors had their clothing, hair and exposed skin covered with an asbestos coating. During filming, Duryea, concerned that the pyrotechnic flames were getting too hot and too close, fled from the set but Basquette, eager to impress director [[Cecil B DeMille]], insisted on remaining until the scene was completed despite the intense heat. The actress suffered serious burns and blistering to her forearms and her eyebrows and lashes were singed.<ref>Basquette, Lina. ''Lina: DeMille's Godless Girl''. Fairfax, VA: Denlinger's Publishers, 1990. p-116-117.</ref> * Unknown film (1929). [[Strongheart]], the [[German Shepherd]] film star, was accidentally burned after coming into contact with a hot studio light. The burn became tumorous, eventually leading to his death later that year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.walkoffame.com/strongheart |title=Strongheart |publisher=[[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] |accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>
==1930s== *''[[Hell's Angels (film)|Hell's Angels]]'' (1930). Three pilots were killed during the filming.<ref name="Flying Magazine">{{cite book|title=Flying Magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZwxbHfALeX0C&pg=PA77|accessdate=4 May 2012|date=April 2006|page=77|issn=0015-4806}}</ref> The sole [[Sikorsky S-29-A]], owned by [[Roscoe Turner]], which portrayed a German [[Gothaer Waggonfabrik|Gotha]] bomber, crashed during filming on 22 March 1929 when stunt pilot Al Wilson put it in a spin for its final scene and was unable to recover. He was ready to bail out and called back to his mechanic Phil Jones (who was in the rear of the plane dumping lampblack to simulate smoke) to jump, but he didn't hear him and went down with the plane. Only one brief shot of the spinning Sikorsky was used in the film.<ref>{{cite book|title=St. Louis Aviation|author=Jeremy R. C. Cox, St Louis Air and Space Museum}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Celluloid Wings|author1=James H. Farmer |author2=Tab Books Inc. }}</ref> * ''[[Such Men Are Dangerous]]'' (1930). During aerial filming off the coast of Southern California near Santa Monica on 2 January 1930, two [[Stinson Detroiter]] aircraft, employed as camera-planes, collided over the ocean. All ten men on board the two planes were killed, including director [[Kenneth Hawks]] (brother of [[Howard Hawks]]), assistant-director Max Gold, cinematographer [[Conrad Wells]], director of photography George Eastman, cameramen Otto Jordan and Ben Frankel, two property men and both pilots. Only five bodies were recovered. As it was one of the final scenes to be filmed, the movie was still completed on schedule. Families of the men who were lost took legal action against Fox Film Company but the courts ruled in favour of the latter.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://scocal.stanford.edu/opinion/parker-v-james-granger-inc-24868 |title=Parker vs. James Granger, Inc. |publisher=[[Stanford University]] |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref><ref name="Deadline Hollywood">{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/04/movies-tv-on-set-deaths-camera-crews-stunts/ |title=Safety On Set: Camera Crew Outnumber Stunt Personnel 4-To-1 In On-Set Deaths |author=Robb, David |publisher=''Deadline Hollywood'' |date=8 April 2014 |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * [[The Viking (1931 film)|''The Viking'']] (1931). After completion of filming in Canada, producer, co-director and real-life adventurer [[Varick Frissell]] decided that more footage of the [[Labrador]] ice floes was required. He and a small film crew joined the real ship ''The Viking'' on a seal-hunting voyage in order to obtain the footage he wanted. On 15 March, the ship became trapped in ice near [[Horse Islands (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Horse Isles]] and dynamite stored on board (intended for breaking up ice floes) accidentally detonated, destroying the vessel and killing 27 men, including Frissell and cameraman Alexander Penrod.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/466486%7C465795/The-Viking.html |title=''The Viking'' |publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies]] |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[Four Frightened People]]'' (1934). During filming in Hawaii, actress [[Claudette Colbert]] was required to stand up to her neck in a real swamp. This scene was shot on her first day on set after having undergone an emergency appendectomy and Colbert and the director disregarded concerns raised by the on-set nurse. Filming in the unsanitary conditions while not yet fully recovered led to Colbert being hospitalized with a severe fever two days later.<ref>Quirk, Lawrence J. ''Claudette Colbert: An Illustrated Biography''. New York: Crown, 1985.p-62.</ref> * [[The Lost Patrol (1934 film)|''The Lost Patrol'']] (1934). During filming in high temperatures in Buttercup Valley near [[Yuma, Arizona]], Director [[John Ford]] insisted his cast and crew only work in the early mornings and late afternoons to avoid the most intense heat of each day. Under pressure from RKO to speed up filming, Producer [[Cliff Reid]] insisted that the midday break be shortened. Ford refused, believing that many of the crew would be at risk of heatstroke in the 120-degree [[Fahrenheit|F]] conditions. Reid tried to prove his point by walking around in the open in the midday heat and soon collapsed with heat exhaustion, requiring hospital treatment.<ref>Nollen, Scott Allen. ''Three Bad Men: John Ford, John Wayne, Ward Bond''. Performing Arts Publishing, 2013. P-56.</ref> *[[The Crusades (film)|''The Crusades'']] (1935). While filming a battle scene in which horses fall into a moat, four stunt riders sustained serious injuries which required hospitalization. All four of their horses were injured so severely they had to be destroyed. It was recommended that the injured stunt-men receive extra pay but director [[Cecil B DeMille]] refused, saying that the riders had 'bungled a simple scene'.<ref>Cary, Diana S. ''The Hollywood Posse: The Story of a Gallant Band of Horsemen who Made Movie History.'' Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1975. p-223-224.</ref> *''[[The Charge of the Light Brigade (1936 film)|The Charge of the Light Brigade]]'' (1936). During the filming of the charge sequence, a stuntman was killed when he fell off his horse and landed on a broken sword that was lying on the field, unfortunately wedged in such a position that its blade was sticking straight up. Also, due to the use of trip wires, three dozen horses had their legs broken and had to be shot during filming, resulting in the U.S. Congress passing laws to protect animals used in motion pictures.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''[[Saratoga (film)|Saratoga]]'' (1937). [[Lionel Barrymore]] broke his hip after tripping on a cable on the set that film.<ref>{{cite web|last=Haun|first=Harry|title=NOISES OFF-BROADWAY AND BEYOND: ''The Old Man and the Moon'' Shines Bright and High Kicks Fill the ''Can-Can''|date=30 September 2014|publisher=''[[Playbill]]''|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/noises-off-broadway-and-beyond-the-old-man-and-the-moon-shines-bright-and-high-kicks-fill-the-can-can-com-331840|accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> *''[[Jesse James (1939 film)|Jesse James]]'' (1939). A horse was killed during the scene where it was ridden off a cliff into a river. This incident led to the [[American Humane Association]] opening a Hollywood office in 1940 and monitoring the treatment of animals in films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/18071/Jesse-James/articles.html|title=Jesse James|author=Jeremy Arnold|website=tcm.com|publisher=Turner Classic Movies|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> * ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' (1939). [[Margaret Hamilton (actress)|Margaret Hamilton]] was badly burned during a scene in which her character, the [[Wicked Witch of the West]], "vanished" in a burst of flame and smoke. A delay in activating a trap door left her exposed to the pyrotechnic device.<ref name="Huffington">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/11/freak-accidents-movie-sets_n_1417983.html |title=13 Freak Accidents On Film Sets: Brandon Lee, Nicole Kidman And Other Celebs (PHOTOS) |author=Gates, Sara |work=[[HuffPost]] |date=13 April 2012 |accessdate=10 April 2013}}</ref> Her [[stunt double]] was also injured in a scene involving a smoking broomstick.<ref>Harmetz, A. (1998). ''The Making of the Wizard of Oz: Movie Magic and Studio Power in the Prime of MGM.'' New York: Hyperion Books.</ref> [[Buddy Ebsen]] suffered a severe allergic reaction to his [[Tin Woodman|Tin Man]] makeup that resulted in a collapsed lung and lifelong breathing issues.<ref>Cox, Stephen (1988, rev. 2003). ''The Beverly Hillbillies: A Fortieth Anniversary Wing Ding''. Cumberland House Publishing; Rev Exp edition. {{ISBN|1-58182-302-9}}.</ref> He was unable to continue working on the production and was replaced by [[Jack Haley]]. *[[Hotel Imperial (1939 film)|''Hotel Imperial'']] (1939). Actor [[Ray Milland]] was seriously injured while filming a cavalry charge scene through a small village. While making a planned jump over an obstacle, the horse's saddle came loose and Milland fell into a pile of masonry. He spent a week in hospital with concussion, a 3-inch gash to his forehead and a badly injured left hand.<ref>Milland, Ray. ''Wide Eyed in Babylon''. New York: Morrow. 1974. p-189.</ref>
==1940s== *''[[Citizen Kane]]'' (1941). While filming, [[Orson Welles]] tripped down a staircase and chipped his anklebone, forcing him to use a wheelchair for the next two weeks. Welles also injured his hand during a scene where he destroyed a room.<ref name="Rosen">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/03/leonardo-dicaprio-django-unchained-hand-injury_n_2230839.html|title=Leonardo DiCaprio's 'Django Unchained' Role Led To Hand Injury|author=Rosen, Christopher|date=3 December 2012|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> *''[[My Life for Ireland]]'' (1941). An anti-British propaganda film made by the Germans. During the epic final battle scene, several extras were killed when one of them stepped on a live land mine. The footage is said to have been included in the release prints, although no proof of this has been established.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''[[They Died with Their Boots On]]'' (1941). Three horsemen perished during the cavalry charge, one of whom was extra Jack Budlong, whose horse tripped as he rode alongside [[Errol Flynn]]. As he fell forward, he had the foresight to toss his sword ahead of him. Unfortunately, it landed handle down and stuck in place. Budlong was impaled on his own sword, and died in a Los Angeles hospital a few hours later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/92817/They-Died-with-Their-Boots-On/articles.html|title=They Died with Their Boots On (1942) - Articles - TCM.com|website=Turner Classic Movies}}</ref> * ''[[Reap the Wild Wind]]'' (1942). According to a biographer, actor [[John Wayne]] suffered a chronic inner-ear condition for the rest of his life after filming under-water scenes in this production.<ref>Davis, Ronald L. ''Duke: The Life and Image of John Wayne''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1998. p-101.</ref> * ''Signed with Their Honour'' (unfinished, 1943). This was to have been a British war film based on the 1942 novel of the same name by [[James Aldridge]]. But during filming in [[Cheshire]], a pair of [[Gloster Gladiator|Gladiator]] biplanes collided, injuring both pilots who managed to escape by parachute. After this incident, the film project was abandoned.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rafcommands.com/archive/13973.php |title=61 OTU and the making of a Gladiator film 1943 |publisher=Royal Air Force Commands |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=68952 |title=ASN Aircraft accident, 24-NOV-1943 Gloster Gladiator MkI K7927 |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[The Royal Mounted Rides Again]]'' (1945). [[Jack Randall (actor)|Addison "Jack" Randall]] was killed at [[Canoga Park]], California, while riding a horse past the cameras at full speed on July 16, 1945, for a [[Universal Pictures]] [[Serial film|serial]], when he fell from the saddle while trying to retrieve his hat which had blown off his head, and struck a tree. He died shortly thereafter.<ref>Associated Press, "Cowboy Actor - Husband Of Barbara Bennett Killed", ''The San Bernardino Daily Sun'', San Bernardino, California, Tuesday 17 July 1945, Volume 51, page 1.</ref> *''[[Unconquered]]'' (1947). During the filming of the historical adventure, nine extras suffered burns including one man who had his hair partially burnt off because director [[Cecil B DeMille]] insisted on using real fireballs and flaming arrows for one of the battle scenes.<ref>Hanson, Patricia K., and Amy Dunkleberger, eds. ''American Film Institute Catalog of Motion Pictures Produced in the United States. Feature films, 1941-1950.'' Film Entries, M-Z. Berkeley: U of California P, 1999. p-2648.</ref> In another incident, stunt woman Polly Burson was filming a scene that required a canoe to go over a waterfall. She missed the tree limb she was supposed to grab onto and fell into the safety net which was below the water's surface. Landing face down in the net, she nearly drowned and was only barely able to struggle upright in time.<ref>Wiener, David J. ''Burns, Falls, and Crashes: Interviews with Movie Stunt Performers''. Jefferson, NC: McFarland, 1996. p-29.</ref>
==1950s== *''[[The Conqueror (1956 film)|The Conqueror]]'' (1956). The exterior scenes were [[shot on location]] near [[St. George, Utah]], {{convert|137|miles|abbr=out}} downwind of the United States government's [[Nevada Test Site]]. In 1953, extensive above-ground [[nuclear weapons]] testing had occurred at the test site, as part of [[Operation Upshot–Knothole]]. Director [[Dick Powell]] died of cancer in January 1963, [[Pedro Armendáriz]] was diagnosed with kidney cancer in 1960, and committed suicide in 1963 after he learned his condition had become terminal. [[Susan Hayward]], [[John Wayne]], and [[Agnes Moorehead]] all died of cancer in the 1970s. Cast member actor [[John Hoyt]] died of lung cancer in 1991. The cast and crew totaled 220 people. By 1981, 91 of them had developed some form of cancer and 46 had died of the disease. Several of Wayne and Hayward's relatives also had cancer scares as well after visiting the set. [[Michael Wayne]] developed skin cancer, his brother [[Patrick Wayne]] had a benign tumor removed from his breast and Hayward's son Tim Barker had a benign tumor removed from his mouth. It is not clear, however, that the cancer rate for this film crew was significantly higher than in the general population. Further, while the cast members noted developed a wide variety of cancers, according to [[The New England Journal of Medicine]], [[leukemia]] is the only form of cancer known to develop from exposure to fallout radiation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gasdetection.com/interscan-in-the-news/magazine-articles/movie-conqueror-really-cursed-look-radiation-paranoia/ |title=Was The Movie ''The Conqueror'' Really Cursed? A Look At Radiation Paranoia |author=Shaw, Michael D. |publisher=Interscan Corporation |date=14 September 2009 |accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=759916 |title=Childhood leukemias associated with fallout from nuclear testing |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=300 |issue=8 |pages=397–402 |publisher=[[National Center for Biotechnology Information]] |date=22 February 1979 |author1=Lyon |first1=J. L |last2=Klauber |first2=M. R |last3=Gardner |first3=J. W |last4=Udall |first4=K. S |doi=10.1056/NEJM197902223000804 }}</ref> *''[[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|The Ten Commandments]]'' (1956). [[Cecil B DeMille]] overcame a minor [[Heart attack]] while climbing down by ladder from the top of the Egyptian city gate set during filming the "take three" of the Exodus sequence. In another incident, during filming of a sand-storm scene, an extra carrying a flaming torch tripped over and the torch set fire to the clothing of a young girl standing next to him. The girl only suffered minor burns thanks to the quick thinking of make-up artist [[Frank Westmore]] who raced over and tore off her burning costume. During the filming of the same scene, several Egyptian extras were bitten by scorpions and a cobra which had been blown out of their burrows in the sand by the artificially generated storm.<ref>Westmore, Frank, and Muriel Davidson. ''The Westmores of Hollywood''. Philadelphia: J.B. Lippincott, 1976. p-159-162.</ref> *''[[Varan the Unbelievable]]'' (1958). Minor injuries, exhaustion and dehydration are common hazards for suit actors of the [[kaiju]] genre, but during the filming of 'Varan' suit actor [[Haruo Nakajima]] (who also portrayed [[Godzilla]] for 18 years) was severely burned due to a pyrotechnics mishap. This was the only time in his career that his injuries forced him to be replaced for the remainder of the shoot.<ref>Lees, J.D. and Cerasini, Marc. (1998). ''The Official Godzilla Compendium'' Random House, p. 28.</ref> *''[[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|Ben-Hur]]'' (1959). Joe Canutt, who was [[Charlton Heston]]'s stunt double, sustained a gash on his chin after being flipped out of his chariot during a chariot race scene.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/stuntman-death-in-ben-hur/ |title=Did a Stuntman Die in ''Ben Hur''? |publisher=[[Snopes.com]] |accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref> *''[[The Horse Soldiers]]'' (1959). Fred Kennedy, a veteran stuntman and bit player, was killed in a horse fall on location in Louisiana. Director [[John Ford]] was so upset he closed the set and had to film the rest of the scene later in the [[San Fernando Valley]], and in a cut-down version.{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}}
==1960s== * [[The Alamo (1960 film)|''The Alamo'']] (1960). Actor [[Laurence Harvey]], who played Colonel [[William Travis|W B Travis]], was injured when a cannon recoiled while firing, with one of the wheels rolling over his foot, fracturing it. He did not reveal his injury until filming of the scene was completed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/entertainment/movies/article/The-Alamo-turns-50-720600.php |title=''The Alamo'' Turns 50 |author=Saldana, Hector |publisher=MySanAntonio.com |date=23 October 2010 |accessdate=21 November 2015}}</ref> * [[Spartacus (film)|''Spartacus'']] (1960). Actor [[Charles McGraw]] suffered a broken jaw on the set of the Roman epic. During the revolt at the Gladiator school, Spartacus ([[Kirk Douglas]]) is seen forcing the head of evil trainer Marcellus (McGraw) into a cauldron of soup, drowning him. McGraw's jaw struck the rim of the pot, sustaining a fracture but he managed to continue the scene nonetheless.<ref>Rode, Alan K. ''Charles McGraw: Biography of a Film Noir Tough Guy''. McFarland & Co, 2007. p187.</ref> * [[The Guns of Navarone (film)|''The Guns of Navarone'']] (1961). Actor [[David Niven]] almost drowned during filming of an ocean storm scene inside a large water tank. He sustained a cut lip that led the actor being hospitalized with septicemia, which halted production on the film for a month. He insisted on returning to complete filming of his scenes before he had fully recovered, later causing a relapse of his illness that resulted in another seven weeks in hospital.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/21984/The-Guns-of-Navarone/articles.html |title=''The Guns of Navarone'' |publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies]] |accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref> * ''[[Cape Fear (1962 film)|Cape Fear]]'' (1962). According to [[Robert Mitchum]], [[Gregory Peck]] accidentally punched him for real during the final fight scene. Mitchum felt the impact for days afterward.<ref>{{cite web|title=GREGORY PECK|date=2 May 2014|publisher=''[[Guyana Chronicle]]''|url=https://guyanachronicle.com/2014/05/02/gregory-peck|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref> * ''[[:ru:Цветок на камне|Flower on Stone]]'' (1962). Soviet actress [[:ru:Бурдученко, Инна Георгиевна|Inna Burduchenko]] suffered third degree burns while filming in a burning [[barracks]] on 30 July 1960. She died in the hospital on 15 August. Burudchenko was three months pregnant at the time of her death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Інна Бурдученко - актриса з трагічною долею|url=http://www.gorod.cn.ua/news_8672.html|website=gorod.cn.ua|accessdate=12 July 2017|language=Russian|date=March 31, 2009}}</ref> * ''[[How the West Was Won (film)|How the West Was Won]]'' (1962). Stuntman Bob Morgan, husband of [[Yvonne De Carlo]], was seriously injured and lost a leg during a break in filming a gunfight on a moving train. Chains holding logs on a flatbed car broke, crushing Morgan as he crouched beside them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/movies/films/westwon.htm|title=How the West Was Won|publisher=[[Snopes]]|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> *''[[Lawrence of Arabia (film)|Lawrence of Arabia]]'' (1962). Actor [[Peter O'Toole]] was nearly killed when he fell from his camel. He also injured his hand during filming by punching through the window of a caravan while drunk. A brace or bandage can be seen on his left thumb during the first train attack scene, presumably due to this incident.{{Citation needed|date=December 2012}} *''[[The Manchurian Candidate (1962 film)|The Manchurian Candidate]]'' (1962). While filming a fight scene with [[Henry Silva]], [[Frank Sinatra]] broke his little finger during a movement where he smashed through a table. This resulted in problems with his hand for several years and is said to be one of the reasons why he pulled out of a starring role in ''[[Dirty Harry]]'', having to undertake surgery to alleviate pains.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://listverse.com/2014/06/07/10-strange-stories-about-frank-sinatra/ |title=10 Strange Stories About Frank Sinatra |author=Moore, Nolan |publisher=Listverse |date=7 June 2014 |accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> * ''[[The War Lover]]'' (1962). During aerial filming over the English Channel, parachutists jumped from a vintage [[B-17]] to simulate a bail-out. One of the jumpers, Englishman Mike Reilly, drowned in the sea below.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pbase.com/easystreet/notes_on_the_filming |title=The Story of the Filming of ''The War Lover'' |author=Jacobson, Jake |accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Dr. Strangelove]]'' (1964). [[Peter Sellers]] was originally to have portrayed a fourth character, Major "King" Kong. However, Sellers injured his ankle while filming a take as Kong. As a result, [[Slim Pickens]] played the role of Kong. [[Scott Simon]] claims the titular character is in a wheelchair because of Sellers' ankle injury.<ref>{{cite web|last2=Simon|first2=Scott|last1=Garcia-Navarro|first1=Lulu|title=Classic Movie Review: 'Dr. Strangelove'|date=19 August 2017|publisher=[[NPR]]|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/08/19/544641105/classic-movie-review-dr-strangelove|accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref> *''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'' (1964). [[Harold Sakata]] burned his hand while filming the fight at Fort Knox, where his character, [[Oddjob]], gets electrocuted, but continued to act as the scene was still being filmed.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Fin Martin |author2=Antohy Evans |lastauthoramp=yes| title = Know their Roles | pages= 26–31 | work = Power Slam Magazine | id = 109 | date = August 2003 | publisher=SW Publishing LTD | location=[[Lancaster, Lancashire]], England}}</ref> *''[[The Flight of the Phoenix (1965 film)|The Flight of the Phoenix]]'' (1965). On 8 July 1965, pilot [[Paul Mantz]] crashed and was killed on a second take making a low pass.<ref name="Flying Magazine"/><ref name="HowStuffWorks">{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/8-stars-who-died-during-the-filming-of-a-movie.htm |title=10 Stars Who Died During the Filming of a Movie |work=HowStuffWorks.com |accessdate=21 December 2012}}</ref> *''[[Lt. Robin Crusoe, U.S.N.]]'' (1965). Cameraman Robert King Baggot was killed during filming in [[Kauai]] when a huge wave hit his boat and washed him overboard.<ref name="Yahoo"/> *''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' (1965). While filming the scene where [[SPECTRE]] agent Angelo crashes the [[Avro Vulcan]] into the ocean near [[The Bahamas]], the stunt double for Angelo nearly drowned when the stunt double for [[Emilio Largo]] accidentally disconnected both the prop oxygen line and the double's actual oxygen line underneath.<ref name="Bahamas">''James Bond in the Bahamas'' featurette, ''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]'' Blu-ray, 2006</ref> *''High Jungle'' (1966). On 28 September 1966, ''[[Rawhide (TV series)|Rawhide]]'' star [[Eric Fleming]] was filming in Peru. During the final stages of shooting, Fleming's dugout canoe overturned in the [[Huallaga River]]. Actor [[Nico Minardos]] managed to swim to safety, but Fleming was swept away by the current and drowned. Fleming was 41 when he died. His body was recovered three days later.{{Citation needed|date=September 2013}} * [[Pontiac]] commercial (1967). Cameraman Raffael John Esposito and actress Brenda Lee Meinsenheimer were killed in [[Thousand Oaks, California]], when a camera boom suspended from an oncoming camera car crashed through the windshield of their car.<ref name="Yahoo"/> *''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' (1968). Crew member Gary Streiner accidentally caught himself on fire while attempting to ignite a prop with gasoline. Actor [[Bill Hinzman]] managed to put out the fire, saving Streiner's life.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jackson|first=Matthew|title=10 Facts About ''Night of the Living Dead''|date=13 October 2017|publisher=''[[Mental Floss]]''|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/91635/10-facts-about-night-living-dead|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=yy-XBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA70&lpg=PA70|last=Kane|first=Joe|title=Night Of The Living Dead: Behind the Scenes of the Most Terrifying Zombie Movie Ever|year=2010|publisher=[[Kensington Books]]|isbn=9780806534312}}page 70</ref> *''[[Battle of Britain (film)|Battle of Britain]]'' (1969). Spanish air force pilot Don Federico Eglesias Lanzo was killed in a crash at [[San Pablo Airport|Tablada]], [[Seville]].<ref name="Farmer1984"/> * ''[[:ru:Директор (фильм, 1969)|Director]]'' (1969). Soviet actor [[Yevgeni Urbansky]] died in an accident while performing a stunt during filming on 5 November 1965.{{Citation needed|date=November 2013}} * ''[[Shark! (film)|Shark!]]'' (1969). A stuntman was mauled to death on camera when a shark, which was supposed to have been sedated, suddenly attacked.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}}
==1970s== * ''[[Barquero]]'' (1970). On August 28, 1969, Director [[Robert Sparr]] was killed in a plane crash while scouting filming locations with cameraman [[Gerald Finnerman]]. The single engine plane they were riding in went down near the Brush Hollow Reservoir outside of [[Penrose, Colorado]]. The pilot was also killed in the crash, but Finnerman survived. One of the film's stars, [[Lee Van Cleef]], was scheduled to accompany Sparr and Finnerman on the scouting trip, but he backed out at the last minute.{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} * ''[[Catch-22 (film)|Catch-22]]'' (1970). Second unit director John Jordan was killed when he was sucked out of a [[B-25 Mitchell]] while filming a bombing scene. He refused to wear a safety harness while the plane was in flight.<ref name="World's Strangest"/> * ''[[Insee thong]]'' (1970). Thai star [[Mitr Chaibancha]] was killed while starring as his popular character, the masked crime-fighter Insee Daeng (Red Eagle). On the final day of shooting, Mitr was required to grab a rope ladder hanging from a helicopter. However he only managed to grab the lowest rung. Unaware of this, the helicopter pilot took off until Mitr finally lost his grip and fell to the ground. The accident was caught on film and appeared in the final theatrical release. The fall was removed from the DVD release version.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tupchai|first=Suchada|title=Adoring fans remember famous Thai film star Mitr Chiabancha|url=http://www.pattayamail.com/586/features.shtml|publisher='Pattaya Mail.}}</ref> * ''[[Tora! Tora! Tora!]]'' (1970). During aerial rehearsals prior to shooting in [[Oahu]], Hawaii, a [[Vultee BT-13]], modified to resemble a Japanese [[Aichi D3A|Val]] dive-bomber, crashed in a sugar-cane field in [[Ewa, Hawaii|Ewa]], killing pilot Guy Thomas Strong.<ref name="Honolulu Star-Bulletin">{{cite news |url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2000/04/17/news/story1.html |title=Mock Japanese Plane Crashes on Ford Island / Movie Plane Crash Isn't the First |author1=Kakesako, Greg |author2=Burlingame, Burl |work=[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |date=17 April 2000 |accessdate=21 November 2015}}</ref> * [[Zeppelin (film)|''Zeppelin'']] (1970). During aerial filming over the Irish Sea, a replica [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5|SE5]] biplane and an [[Aérospatiale SA 318C Alouette II|Alouette]] helicopter camera-ship collided in mid-air. Assistant-director Burch Williams (brother of producer [[Elmo Williams]]), cameraman Skeets Kelly and pilots Jim Liddy and Gilbert Chomat were all killed.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=18989 |title=ASN Aircraft accident 18-AUG-1970 Aérospatiale SA 318C Alouette II G-AWEE |publisher=''Aviation Safety Network'' |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[A Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]]'' (1971). During the film's pivotal brainwashing scene, [[Malcolm McDowell]] suffered a scratched cornea and temporary blindness from having his eyes propped open for so long.<ref name="Mandatory">{{cite web|url=http://www.mandatory.com/2013/05/30/10-bizarre-on-set-injuries-of-famous-movie-stars/|title=10 Bizarre On-Set Injuries of Famous Movie Stars|author=Dudak, Cory|date=30 May 2013|publisher=''Mandatory''|accessdate=30 September 2013}}</ref> McDowell also suffered a broken rib in the scene in which an actor taunts and attacks him to demonstrate his rehabilitation.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} * ''[[Kamen Rider]]'' (1971). During a scene for Episode 9 ("The Terrifying Cobra-Man"), lead actor [[Hiroshi Fujioka]] fractured his [[thighbone]] in a motorcycle stunt when he rode into a [[telephone pole]] at 50 mph, forcing him out of action. Producers had to use stock and unused footage, which was dubbed by Rokurô Naya, for the next four episodes, causing a dip in the ratings. Producers eventually had no choice but to substitute him with a second character played by Takeshi Sasaki. Fujioka made a return in Episode 53 ("Monster Jaguarman – Deathmatch by Motorcycle Fight"). As neither actor could be axed, the show ended up having two heroes.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} *''[[Von Richthofen and Brown]]'' (1971). Stunt pilot Charles Boddington was killed during filming when the vintage biplane he was flying crashed at Weston aerodrome near Dublin. The following day, another aircraft crashed, injuring pilot [[Lynn Garrison]] and actor [[Don Stroud]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/94914/Von-Richthofen-and-Brown/notes.html |title=''Von Richthofen and Brown'' (1971) - Notes |publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies]] |accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref> *''[[Deliverance]]'' (1972). [[Burt Reynolds]] injured his coccyx while canoeing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Guerrasio|first=Jason|title=Burt Reynolds remembers his legendary career and the most dangerous stunt he ever did|date=20 March 2016|publisher=''[[Business Insider]]''|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/burt-reynolds-interview-2016-3|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Riefe |first=Jordan |title="Deliverance": Of dunking and dummies 40 years on |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/entertainment-us-deliverance/deliverance-of-dunking-and-dummies-40-years-on-idUSBRE86213120120703 |accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Boucher|first=Geoff|title='Deliverance' crew returns to the river|date=17 June 2012|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jun/17/entertainment/la-ca-deliverance-20120617|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> In addition, screenwriter [[James Dickey]] allegedly broke film director [[John Boorman]]'s nose and knocked out some of his teeth.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lyttelton|first=Oliver|title=5 Things You Might Not Know About 'Deliverance,' Released 40 Years Ago Today|date=30 July 2012|publisher=[[IndieWire]]|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2012/07/5-things-you-might-not-know-about-deliverance-released-40-years-ago-today-251460/|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> *''[[Enter the Dragon]]'' (1972). During a fight scene, [[Robert Wall]] accidentally slashed [[Bruce Lee]] in the arm with a broken bottle. After the wound healed, Lee legitimately kicked Wall during the re-shoot with such force that an extra broke his arm trying to catch Wall.<ref name="Cracked">{{cite web |url=http://www.cracked.com/article_20589_6-amazing-performances-by-actors-who-werent-acting-part-2.html |title=6 Amazing Performances by Actors Who Weren't Acting Part 2 |author1=Marchetti, David |author2=Mannen, Amanda |author3=Short, Aaron |author4=DuBonnet, Miles |author5=Kohlmorgen, Matthew |work=[[Cracked (magazine)|Cracked]] |date=4 September 2013 |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> *''[[The Godfather]]'' (1972). [[Gianni Russo]] broke two ribs and cracked his elbow after [[James Caan]] threw him over a fence and slammed a garbage can on him during a fight scene.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.time.com/2012/03/15/the-anniversary-you-cant-refuse-40-things-you-didnt-know-about-the-godfather/slide/a-too-realistic-fight/ |title=The Anniversary You Can't Refuse: 40 Things You Didn't Know About The Godfather |author=Rawlings, Nate |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=16 February 2017}}</ref> *''[[The Last Lion]]'' (1972). Sound technician James Chapman was mauled to death by a lion during production on this South African film.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} *''[[Napoleon and Samantha]]'' (1972). [[Jodie Foster]] was mauled by a lion on the set. The event has since caused Foster to suffer from [[ailurophobia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Lion Mauling Left Foster Fearful Of Cats|date=1 April 2008|publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]]|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/jodie-foster/news/lion-mauling-left-foster-fearful-of-cats_1064316|accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref> *''The Bell from Hell'' (1973). On the final day of shooting of this Spanish/French horror film, director Claudio Guerrin Hill died after falling from the bell tower for which he named his film. He either jumped or fell accidentally. Juan Antonio Bardem came in to take care of the post production duties after Hill's death.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''La Cloche Tibétaine'' (1973). On June 18, during the filming of episode 4, L'escadron d'or (The Golden Squandron), of this French mini-series, actor [[Roger Delgado]] and two Turkish film technicians were killed when their car went off of the road and fell into a ravine. Delgado, who was most famous for his role as [[the Master (Doctor Who)|the Master]] in the British film series ''[[Doctor Who]]'', was 55 at the time of his death.{{Citation needed|date=July 2016}} *''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]'' (1973). [[Linda Blair]] suffered a spinal fracture due to a mechanical failure while filming a scene where her character [[Regan MacNeil]] levitates and thrashes violently. The fracture later developed into [[scoliosis]] years later after Blair reinjured her back during a motorcycle scene in another film.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hudsonvalleyscoliosis.com/linda-blair-scoliosis/ |title=Linda Blair - Actress |publisher=Hudson Valley Scoliosis Correction Center |access-date=3 December 2017}}</ref> In addition, actress [[Ellen Burstyn]] seriously injured her back while filming a scene where she falls over backwards after her possessed daughter backhands her. The scene was left in the film.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} *''Primal Man (TV)'' (1974). Actor/stunt performer [[Janos Prohaska]], his son Robert, and 34 others died in an airplane crash while filming this television series.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/PrimalMan-N4819C.htm |title=The "Primal Man" Crash |publisher=Check-Six.com |date=13 March 1974 |accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> *''[[The Eiger Sanction (film)|The Eiger Sanction]]'' (1975). A number of accidents occurred during the filming of ''The Eiger Sanction''. A 27-year-old English climber, David Knowles, who was a body double and photographer, was killed during a rock fall, and mountaineer [[Mike Hoover]] narrowly escaped with his life.<ref name="Eliot161">Eliot (2009), p.161</ref> * ''[[The Great Waldo Pepper]]'' (1975). Experienced stunt pilot [[Frank Tallman]], during filming of the aerial scenes, managed to perform two planned crashes without injury. However a third (accidental) crash occurred while landing a [[Nieuport 28|Nieuport]] biplane when a rudder bar broke at 400 feet, sending his aircraft nose-diving into a hill. Tallman survived but suffered two cracked vertebrae and he required 58 stitches and had to be taken off filming for two weeks.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1346&dat=19750413&id=GVtNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=C_sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6686,2961140 |title=''Waldo Pepper'' Stuntman Pleased with Movie Results |author=Gelmis, Joseph |work=[[The Ledger|Lakeland Ledger]] |date=13 April 1975 |accessdate=30 November 2015}}</ref> * ''[[Hand of Death]]'' (1976). According to his book ''[[I Am Jackie Chan]]: My Life in Action'', [[Jackie Chan]] was knocked unconscious when he did one of the stunts on this film.<ref name="I Am Jackie Chan">{{cite web |url=http://www.randomhouse.com/features/iamjackiechan/excerpt_aches.html |title=Jackie's Aches and Pains: It Only Hurts When I'm Not Laughing |author=Jackie Chan|author-link=Jackie Chan |publisher=[[Random House]] |accessdate=19 December 2012}}</ref> * ''[[The Omen]]'' (1976). [[Gregory Peck]] accidentally slammed a car door on the hand of Guglielmo Spoletini, who portrayed the Italian taxi driver. According to [[Bloody Disgusting]], Spoletini's finger was almost amputated.<ref name=kurland/> * ''[[A Bridge Too Far (film)|A Bridge Too Far]]'' (1977). Stuntman [[Alf Joint]] was seriously injured while performing a stunt in which he jumped off a roof. Joint said of the experience that he felt he was being "pushed." In addition, special effects director [[John Richardson (special effects designer)|John Richardson]] and his assistant [[Liz Moore]] were involved in a car crash which killed Moore. Both the car accident and Joint's injury are alleged to have been attributed by the "curse" of the 1976 film ''The Omen'', which Joint and Richardson also participated in.<ref name=kurland>{{cite web|last=Kurland|first=Daniel|title=Looking at the Horrible, Cursed Production of 'The Omen'!|date=19 April 2016|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/movie/3386555/looking-horrible-cursed-production-omen/|accessdate=17 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Curse of the OMEN and other Hollywood hexes From The Omen to The Exorcist and Rosemary's Baby there are tales of fatal accidents, devil worship, doomed planes and car crashes ... Barry Didcock looks at some of the most cursed films of all time and|date=22 October 2005|publisher=''[[The Herald (Scotland)]]''|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12474820.Curse_of_the_OMEN_and_other_Hollywood_hexes_From_The_Omen_to_The_Exorcist_and_Rosemary_apos_s_Baby_there_are_tales_of_fatal_accidents__devil_worship__doomed_planes_and_car_crashes_______Barry_Didcock_looks_at_some_of_the_most_cursed_films_of_all_time_and_/|accessdate=17 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Conradt|first=Stacy|title=13 Foreboding Facts About ''The Omen''|date=25 June 2016|publisher=''[[Mental Floss]]''|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/70457/13-foreboding-facts-about-omen|accessdate=17 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dobbs|first=Sarah|title=Is The Dark Knight cursed?|date=5 August 2008|publisher=[[Den of Geek]]|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/us/movies/batman/13533/is-the-dark-knight-cursed|accessdate=17 September 2017}}</ref> * ''[[Attack of the Killer Tomatoes]]'' (1978). The [[Hiller UH-12]] helicopter crash involving [[Jack Riley (actor)|Jack Riley]] and George Wilson was entirely unintentional, but having not been seriously injured both actors continued by ad-libbing the rest of the scene, and ultimately it was included in the film.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.check-six.com/lib/Movie_Crash2.htm | title=Movie Crash from Attack of the Killer Tomatoes, July 11, 1978 | accessdate=21 December 2012}}</ref> * ''[[Comes a Horseman]]'' (1978). Filming the scene where [[Jason Robards]]' character is dragged (presumably) to his death, his stunt double Jim Sheppard was killed when a horse that was dragging him veered from its course and caused him to hit his head on a fence post. The scene made it into the film, although it was cut right before the horse passed through the gate that killed Sheppard.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} * ''[[Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1978 film)|Invasion of the Body Snatchers]]'' (1978). While filming a scene of his character running, [[Donald Sutherland]] got hit by a car.<ref>{{cite web|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About... Invasion of the Body Snatchers|date=11 May 2017|publisher=[[HMV]]|url=http://www.hmv.com/video/10-things-you-didn-t-know-about-invasion-of-the-body-snatchers|accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> * ''[[Snake in the Eagle's Shadow]]'' (1978). Actor [[Hwang Jang Lee]] knocked off one of Jackie Chan's teeth after kicking him in the face during a fight scene. Chan's arm was also slashed by a sword that was supposed to be blunt, but the camera kept rolling as he was screaming in pain.<ref name="I Am Jackie Chan"/> * ''[[Apocalypse Now]]'' (1979). In the film's opening scene, [[Martin Sheen]] cut his hand after smashing a mirror; he was too drunk to realize that his hand was streaming in blood. During filming on 5 March 1977, Sheen suffered a heart attack. He returned on the set six weeks later.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1233293/The-maddest-movie-Why-Apocalypse-Now-finest-film-modern-times.html |title=The maddest movie ever: Why Apocalypse Now is the finest film of modern times |author=Rennell, Tony |work=[[The Daily Mail]] |date=5 December 2009 |accessdate=28 May 2014}}</ref> * ''[[CHiPs]]'' (1979). While filming an episode, [[Erik Estrada]] lost control of his motorcycle and was hurled into a parked car before the 900-pound motorcycle landed on him. Estrada sustained fractured ribs, partially collapsed lungs, a fractured right wrist, and a cracked sternum and clavicle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20074479,00.html |title=Erik Estrada, CHiPs' Vain and Glorious Hero, Revs Up Again Despite a Near-Fatal Crackup |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=3 September 1979 |accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1842&dat=19790801&id=5wosAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dcgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1209,1116398 |title=TV Actor Erik Estrada Hurt in Cycle Accident |work=[[TimesDaily]] |date=1 August 1979 |accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> * ''Revenge'' (1979). Director [[Gordon Parks, Jr.]], cameraman Peter Gilfillian, and two others were killed in a plane crash while filming in [[Kenya]].<ref name="Yahoo"/> * ''Steel'' (1979). [[A.J. Bakunas]] died doubling for [[George Kennedy]] in a fall from the [[Kincaid Towers]] in [[Lexington, Kentucky]]. Bakunas had successfully performed a fall from the ninth floor of the construction site, but when he learned that [[Dar Robinson]] had broken his record high fall for a non-film related publicity stunt, Bakunas returned to perform the fall from the top of the {{convert|300|ft|m|adj=on}} construction site.
