Bakunas performed the fall expertly, but the airbag split and he was killed.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19780922&id=BE1QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=41gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4116,1342689 |title=Stuntman Dies Of Injuries In Record Attempt; Man Leaps To His Death At Nashville Hotel |work=[[Evening Independent]] |date=22 September 1978 |accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref>
==1980s== *''[[The Dukes of Hazzard]]'' (1980). Assistant cameraman Rodney Mitchell was killed and eight other crew members were injured when their camera truck flipped while rehearsing a chase scene.<ref name="Yahoo"/> *''[[Kolilakkam]]'' (1980). Indian actor [[Jayan]] was killed during a stunt scene where the helicopter he was boarding on crashed.<ref>{{cite news|last=James|first=Anu|title=Remembering 'Kolilakkam' superstar Jayan on his 35th death anniversary|url=https://www.ibtimes.co.in/remembering-kolilakkam-superstar-jayan-his-35th-death-anniversary-654971|accessdate=2 September 2018|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=16 November 2015}}</ref> *''[[Magnum, P.I.]]'' (1980). Cameraman Rob Van Der Kar was killed in a helicopter crash while filming an episode.<ref name="Yahoo"/> *''[[That's Incredible!]]'' (1980). On July 6, stunt motorcyclist Steve Lewis suffered extensive foot and knee injuries while attempting to jump over two cars speeding toward him at over 100 mph.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19800916&id=KWdQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iVgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3571,19501 |title=Cyclist Critically Hurt After Jump for TV's ''That's Incredible!'' |work=[[Evening Independent]] via [[Google News]] |date=16 September 1980 |accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref> On September 15, while performing a 170-foot jump over the fountains of [[Caesars Palace]] in [[Paradise, Nevada]], stunt motorcyclist [[Gary Wells (motorcyclist)|Gary Wells]] missed the landing ramp and crashed into a parking lot wall. He sustained a tear in the main artery of his heart, along with broken legs, a fractured pelvis, and a concussion. In addition, six spectators were injured when a 15-foot section of the wall gave way upon impact.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blogs.denverpost.com/sports/2014/09/10/motorcyclist-gary-wells-57-set-jump-150-feet-colorado-national-speedway/26785/ |title=Motorcyclist Gary Wells, 57, set to jump 150 feet at Colorado National Speedway |author=Chambers, Mike |work=[[The Denver Post]] |date=10 September 2014 |accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Das Boot]]'' (1981). While filming a scene in which the {{GS|U-96|1940|2}} is caught in a storm, actor [[Jan Fedder]] lost his footing and was nearly swept off the conning tower set. Actor [[Bernd Tauber]] noticed Fedder was suddenly missing and cried out, ''"Mann-über-Bord!"'' ("Man overboard!"). With the cameras still rolling, Tauber helped him to the conning tower hatch. Director [[Wolfgang Petersen]] did not realize at first that it was an accident and said, "Good idea, Jan. We'll do that one more time!" before it came upon him. Fedder was hospitalized and his role was partially rewritten so that he was bed-ridden for a short portion of the film. The footage was developed and the scene in which Fedder's character is nearly swept off the submarine is one of the most memorable moments in the film.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} * ''[[The Cannonball Run#Litigation|The Cannonball Run]]'' (1981). Stuntwoman Heidi von Beltz was left a [[paraplegic]] after being thrown from her car during a crash.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.exponent.com/cannonball_run/|title=Cannonball Run Accident|publisher=Exponent|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref><ref>''Interstate Fire & Cas. Co. v. Stuntman Inc.'', 861 F.2d 203 (9th Cir. 1988).</ref> She died in October 2015, 35 years after the accident, aged 59.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Robb|first1=David|title=Heidi von Beltz Dies: Stuntwoman Paralyzed In 'Cannonball Run' Crash Was 59|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/heidi-von-beltz-dead-stuntwoman-paralyzed-cannonball-run-crash-1201597841/|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=29 October 2015}}</ref> * ''[[The Five of Me]]'' (1981). Camera assistant Jack Tandberg was killed when he was struck by a driverless stunt car during filming of this made-for-television film.<ref name="Yahoo"/> * ''[[For Your Eyes Only (film)|For Your Eyes Only]]'' (1981). While filming a high speed chase in the bobsleigh run, the four-man bobsled came out of the run at the wrong place and hit a tree. One of its occupants, a young stuntman named Paolo Rigon, was killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universalexports.net/Tidbits/eyesonly.shtml|title=Bond titbits|publisher=Universal Exports.net|accessdate=6 May 2012}}</ref> In the scene where [[James Bond]] and [[Judy Havelock|Melina Havelock]] are dragged across the ocean, the stunt doubles for both characters suffered cuts and lacerations when their backs scraped against the [[coral reef]] in the Bahamas.<ref name="Bahamas"/> *''[[Roar (1981 film)|Roar]]'' (1981). A film about a wildlife preservationist whose family came to visit him only to be met with his co-habitats, his vast collection of wild animals, which unfortunately attacked the film crew and actors who had to work alongside with, leaving over 70 of them injured on set<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interestingamerica.com/2010-11-24_Shambala_Preserve_Grigonis.html |title=Shambala Preserve, Acton, California |publisher=Interestingamerica.com |date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20068274,00.html |title=Tippi Hedren Learns the Law of the Jungle: When An Elephant Decides to Ad Lib, Look Out |publisher=People.com |date= |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> including cinematographer [[Jan de Bont]], who had his scalp lifted by a lion, resulting in 220 stitches. Lead actress [[Tippi Hedren]] fractured her leg and also had scalp wounds after being bucked off by an elephant while she was riding it in addition to being also bitten in the neck by a lion and required 38 stitches. [[Melanie Griffith]] (Hedren's daughter) was also attacked, receiving 50 stitches to her face.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soundonsight.org/watch-the-trailer-for-re-release-roar-the-most-dangerous-film-ever-made/ |title=Watch a trailer for the re-release of 'Roar', the most dangerous film ever made |publisher=Soundonsight.org |date=11 March 2015 |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> Because of the injuries on set, crew turnover was high as many never returned on set.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jon Stobezki |url=http://drafthousefilms.com/blog/entry/utterly-brainsick-roar-starring-tippi-hedren-melanie-griffith-joins-pride-o |title=Utterly Terrifying ROAR, Starring Tippi Hedren & Melanie Griffith, Joins Pride Of |publisher=Drafthousefilms.com |date=19 February 2015 |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earthporm.com/family-lived-real-lion-back-1971/ |title=This Family Lived With A Real Lion Back In 1971 |publisher=Earthporm.com |date= |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flixist.com/drafthouse-films-releasing-the-bizarre-lion-filled-cult-movie-roar-219008.phtml |title=Drafthouse Films releasing the bizarre lion-filled cult movie Roar |publisher=Flixist.com |date=20 February 2015 |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> John Marshall was bitten by one of the lions and required 56 stitches.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083001/trivia|title=Roar (1981) : Trivia|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alfredhitchcockgeek.com/2012_10_01_archive.html |title=October 2012 |publisher=Alfred Hitchcock Geek |date= |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://moviehooker.com/movies/trailer-for-roar-the-most-dangerous-film-ever-made/ |title=Trailer For 'Roar' – The Most Dangerous Film Ever Made |publisher=MovieHooker |date=11 March 2015 |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/63263326/ |title=Santa Cruz Sentinel from Santa Cruz, California · Page 6 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=9 July 1978 |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> *''[[The Sword and the Sorcerer]]'' (1981). Stuntman Jack Tyree was killed while doing a high fall stunt at [[Griffith Park]] in Los Angeles. While performing a 78-foot fall in heavy costume and makeup, Tyree struck his airbag off center, resulting in a fatal impact.<ref>Movie stuntman Jack Tyree was killed in the filming of the scene on 25 August 1981, falling 180 feet and missing a large airbag by two feet, "Stuntman dies doing dive", The Calgary Herald – 27 August 1981, pB-15</ref> *''That's Incredible!'' (1981). In March 1981 in [[Puʻunene, Hawaii]], Australian stuntman Jim Bailey attempted to [[Hang gliding|hang glide]] on the underside of a single-engine airplane, but upon takeoff, his safety harness snapped, leaving him dangling under the front landing gear about 500 feet above ground before falling to his death.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1243&dat=19810331&id=pF0zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EPcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4914,1102651 |title=Stuntman dies in fall from plane |work=[[The Bulletin (Bend)|The Bulletin]] via [[Google News]] |date=31 March 1981 |accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref> *''[[Blade Runner]]'' (1982). [[Daryl Hannah]] chipped her elbow in eight places during a scene where she accidentally slipped on the pavement and smashed the window of a parked car.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/blogs/the-movies-blog/10-things-you-never-knew-about-blade-runner-759354 |title=10 Things You Never Knew About Blade Runner |author=Levine, Nick |publisher=[[NME]] |date=27 March 2015 |accessdate=16 February 2017}}</ref> *''[[First Blood]]'' (1982). In the scene where [[John Rambo]] jumped off a cliff and used a tree to break his fall, [[Sylvester Stallone]] broke several ribs after filming the scene three times. He also suffered bruises to his back after 19 takes of the jail scene where Deputy Art Galt ([[Jack Starrett]]) clubbed Rambo with a nightstick.<ref name="Cracked"/> Stunt driving for [[Brian Dennehy]], Bennie E. Dobbins suffered a lumbar compression fracture.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0229609/bio? |title=Bennie E. Dobbins - Biography - IMDb |publisher=[[IMDb]] |accessdate= Oct 17, 2018}}</ref> *''[[Pink Floyd – The Wall]]'' (1982). During the filming of the scene for the song "[[One of My Turns]]", in which the main character tears apart his hotel room, [[Bob Geldof]] injured his left hand while ripping off pieces of a wooden closet door; he can be seen briefly looking at his hand. Later in the scene, he is then seen with a shirt wrapped around his hand.{{Citation needed|date=November 2013}} *''[[World War III (TV miniseries)|World War III]]'' (1982). During filming for this made-for-TV movie, director [[Boris Sagal]] was fatally injured when his skull was fractured as he walked into the tail rotor blade of a helicopter.<ref name="NYTimes">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/24/obituaries/boris-sagal-58-movie-director-dies-after-a-helicopter-accident.html |title=BORIS SAGAL, 58, MOVIE DIRECTOR, DIES AFTER A HELICOPTER ACCIDENT |author=Kennedy, Shawn G |publisher=''New York Times'' |date=24 May 1981 |accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> *Untitled Australian TV commercial (1982). Cameraman Garry Hansen and two others were killed in a helicopter crash.<ref name="Yahoo"/> *''[[Coolie (1983 Hindi film)|Coolie]]'' (1983). While filming a fight scene with [[Puneet Issar]], [[Amitabh Bachchan]] was critically injured when he jumped over a table and the corner of the table struck his abdomen, resulting in a [[splenic rupture]] and blood loss. Filming was delayed for several months for Bachchan to recover from his injury.<ref name="MensXP">{{cite web |url=http://www.mensxp.com/entertainment/bollywood/8836-10-filming-accidents-in-bollywood-history.html |title=10 Filming Accidents in Bollywood History |author=Saikia, Priyankee |publisher=''MensXP'' |date=3 May 2013 |accessdate=3 October 2013}}</ref> * ''[[High Road to China]]'' (1983). During filming in Yugoslavia, a helicopter crashed en route to location. All three on board–copter pilot Nigel Thornton, stunt pilot David Perrin and mechanic Jaron Anderson–were killed in the crash.<ref name="Deadline Hollywood 2">{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/04/helicopter-crash-deaths-hollywood-safety-history/ |title=Safety On Set: Helicopter Crashes Have Taken Most Lives On TV And Film Sets |author=Robb, David |publisher=''Deadline Hollywood'' |date=8 April 2014 |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[Midnite Spares]]'' (1983). Focus-puller David Brostoff was killed when, during filming of a motor race scene at [[Granville, New South Wales|Granville]], Australia, one of the sprint-cars swerved off the track and struck him, driving his body through two fences. The filmmakers were criticized for a lack of a proper stunt coordinator at the scene and for allowing non-stunt drivers to drive at race-speed.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19820326&id=nP1jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UucDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7035,8887340 |title=Questions raised over film stunt death |author=Brown, Malcolm |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=26 March 1982 |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> *Peterborough jump (1983). On September 5, 1983, Canadian stuntman [[Ken Carter (stuntman)|Ken Carter]] attempted to jump a pond in [[Peterborough, Ontario]], with a rocket-powered [[Pontiac Firebird]]. He overshot the target landing ramp and was killed when his car crashed on its roof.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19830906&id=EaQyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D-8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3674,1842406 |title=Stuntman Ken Carter dies in rocket-car wreck |work=[[Ottawa Citizen]] |date=6 September 1983 |accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref> *''[[The Right Stuff (film)|The Right Stuff]]'' (1983). Stuntman Joseph Leonard Svec died while performing a parachute jump that recreated [[Chuck Yeager]]'s escape from a stalling [[NF-104]]. In real life, Yeager's [[flight helmet]] had caught fire on colliding with the [[ejection seat]]'s heated exhaust in mid-air. Svec carried a smoke canister during his freefall to simulate such fire. However, this may have intoxicated the stuntman, causing him to lose consciousness. He failed to open his [[parachute]] and fell to his death.<ref name=Check-Six>{{cite web|title=The Luckiest Green Beret of Vietnam...|url=http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/TheRightStuff-Svec.htm|work=Check-Six.com|accessdate=10 April 2013}}</ref> *''[[Scarface (1983 film)|Scarface]]'' (1983). Production was stalled for two weeks because [[Al Pacino]] accidentally burned his hand by holding a barrel of a gun that had been fired.<ref name=klimek/><ref name=newman/> *''[[Twilight Zone: The Movie]]'' (1983). On 23 July 1982, [[Vic Morrow]] and child actors Myca Dinh Le (aged 7) and Renee Shin-Yi Chen (aged 6) were [[Twilight Zone accident|killed by a helicopter]] during production when it was caught in the pyrotechnics flying low at 25 feet (8 metres).<ref name="World's Strangest"/><ref name="nine"/> The tail rotor decapitated Morrow and Le and crushed Chen to death.<ref name="nine"/> The accident led to one of the most prolonged lawsuits in film history and resulted in some major changes in filming codes.<ref name="nine"/> *''[[City Heat]]'' (1984). [[Burt Reynolds]] suffered a [[Temporomandibular joint dysfunction|broken jaw]] after being hit on the face with a metal chair while filming a fight scene. The injury left him restricted to a liquid diet; he lost 30 lbs. by the time filming wrapped.<ref name=reynolds>{{cite web|title=Reynolds recounts close calls|date=25 July 2012|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)]]''|url=https://variety.com/2012/film/news/reynolds-recounts-close-calls-1118057051/|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> *''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]'' (1984). In June 1983, while filming in London, [[Harrison Ford]] herniated a disc in his back, forcing him to fly back to Los Angeles for an operation. He returned six weeks later.<ref> {{Cite book | author=Rinzer, J. W. | year = 2008 | title = The Complete Making of Indiana Jones: The Definitive Story Behind All Four Films | publisher=Del Rey, imprint of Random House, Inc. | location = New York | page = 153 | isbn = 978-0-345-50129-5 | quote = Lucas arrived on June 20, [1983]. "Harrison was in really terrible pain", he says. "He was on the set lying on a gurney. They would lift him up and he'd walk through his scenes, and they'd get him back on the bed." That same day Ford filmed his fight with the Thuggee assassin in Indy's suite on Stage 3. "Harrison had to roll backward on top of the guy", Spielberg says. "At that moment his back herniated and Harrison let out a call for help." }}</ref><ref name="Harrison Ford">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/2016/07/26/harrison-ford-and-other-injury-prone-stars/|title=Harrison Ford and Other Injury Prone Stars|author=Vincent, Alice|date=26 July 2016|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> *''[[Cover Up (TV series)|Cover Up]]'' (1984). While waiting for an episode filming to resume, actor [[Jon-Erik Hexum]] played [[Russian roulette]] with a [[.44 Magnum]] loaded with a [[Blank (cartridge)|blank]]. The gunshot fractured his skull and caused massive cerebral hemorrhaging when bone fragments were forced through his brain. He was rushed to Beverly Hills Medical Center, where he was pronounced brain dead.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,304026,00.html |title=Jon-Erik Hexum's Fatal Joke |date=14 October 1994 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |accessdate=5 February 2013}}</ref> * [[Pepsi]] commercial (1984). While [[Michael Jackson]] was filming a television commercial with his [[The Jackson 5|siblings]] at the [[Shrine Auditorium]] in Los Angeles, a faulty pyrotechnic went off too early and set his hair on fire, inflicting second- and third-degree burns to his scalp and body. Jackson sued [[PepsiCo]] for damages and received a US$1.5 million settlement, which he donated to the [[Brotman Medical Center]] in [[Culver City, California]], to establish the Michael Jackson Burn Center for Children. It is widely believed by unnamed sources{{Who|date=April 2018}} that this accident resulted in Jackson's addiction to painkillers and obsession with plastic surgery until his death in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1616411/pepsi-questions-why-michael-jackson-accident-video-was-shared/ |title=Pepsi Questions Why Michael Jackson Accident Video Was Shared |author=Kaufman, Gil |publisher=[[MTV]] |date=16 July 2009 |accessdate=14 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Police Story (1985 film)|Police Story]]'' (1985). During the film's famous pole sliding scene, Jackie Chan suffered third-degree burns on his hands, nearly broke the seventh and eighth vertebrae on his spine, dislocated his pelvis, and was nearly paralyzed. Also, in the scene where Jackie Chan stops a double-decker bus, the actors were supposed to be thrown through the front window of the second level and land on a car below, but instead they landed right on the hard surface of the road, missing the car. The scene still went into the film.<ref name="I Am Jackie Chan"/> *''[[Rambo: First Blood Part II]]'' (1985). During filming in Mexico, FX man Cliff Wenger, Jr. was accidentally killed by one of the film's explosions.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''[[Rocky IV]]'' (1985). Demanding a sense of realism in the boxing match between [[Rocky Balboa]] and [[Ivan Drago]], Sylvester Stallone and [[Dolph Lundgren]] agreed to legitimately spar with each other. Stallone was airlifted from Canada to St. John's Hospital in [[Santa Monica, California]], and placed on intensive care for eight days after Lundgren delivered a hard punch to his chest, causing his heart to swell and his blood pressure to exceed 200.<ref name="AICN">{{cite web | url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/30932 | title=Stallone Interview With Ain't It Cool News | publisher=Ain't It Cool News |accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="BBC"/> * ''[[Runaway Train (film)|Runaway Train]]'' (1985). During filming in Alaska, a helicopter en route to location struck power lines and crashed, killing pilot Rick Holley.<ref name="Deadline Hollywood 2"/> * ''[[Armour of God (film)|Armour of God]]'' (1986). During the filming of a scene in which Jackie Chan jumped from a wall to a tree branch, Chan lost his grip on the branch and fell 15 feet to the ground below. He hit his head on a rock, causing part of his skull to crack and a fragment to lodge in his brain. He now has a plastic plug in a permanent hole in his skull and hearing loss in the right ear.<ref name="I Am Jackie Chan"/> * ''[[Vendetta dal futuro]]'' (''Hands of Steel'', 1986). During filming of the Italian sci-fi action film in Arizona, a helicopter attempted to fly beneath the [[Navajo Bridge]] but crashed, killing the pilot Dan Nasca and Italian actor [[Claudio Cassinelli]].<ref name="Deadline Hollywood 2"/> *''[[Maximum Overdrive]]'' (1986). [[Director of photography]] [[Armando Nannuzzi]] was seriously injured when a radio-controlled lawnmower used in a scene went out of control and struck a block of wood used as a camera support, shooting out wood splinters. The splinters were fired at Nannuzzi's face, resulting in him losing an eye. Nannuzzi sued [[Stephen King]] on 18 February 1987, for $18 million in damages due to unsafe working practices. The suit was settled out of court.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''[[Top Gun]]'' (1986). On 16 September 1985, aerobatic pilot [[Art Scholl]] crashed his [[Pitts S-2]] camera-plane off the southern Californian coast near [[Carlsbad, California|Carlsbad]] and neither was recovered.<ref name="Huffington"/><ref name="World's Strangest"/><ref name="nine">{{cite web|url=http://www.oddee.com/item_96604.aspx|title=9 Worst Movie Set Disasters|work=Oddee.com|accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Missing – Art Scholl|url=http://www.check-six.com/lib/Famous_Missing/Scholl.htm|work=Check-Six.com|accessdate=10 April 2013}}</ref> * ''[[The Wraith]]'' (1986). During filming of a car chase scene in the low-budget sci-fi action film in Arizona, assistant cameraman Bruce Ingram was killed when an overloaded camera car crashed on a mountain road.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref name="Deadline Hollywood"/> * [[Full Metal Jacket (film)|''Full Metal Jacket'']] (1987). Actor [[Vincent D'Onofrio]], who had deliberately increased his weight to 280 pounds in order to play the overweight Marine recruit, twisted his knee during filming of the boot-camp scenes, injuring it so badly, it required surgical reconstruction.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/movies/the-trama-of-being-a-kubrick-marine.html |title=The Trama of Being a Kubrick Marine |author=Bennetts, Leslie |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=10 July 1987 |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Million Dollar Mystery]]'' (1987). Stuntman [[Dar Robinson]] died in a motorcycle accident after a dangerous stunt had been filmed and the medics on the set had been dismissed. Robinson, famous for his jumps off Toronto's [[CN Tower]] drove his motorcycle off a cliff.<ref name="World's Strangest"/> *''[[The Squeeze (1987 film)|The Squeeze]]'' (1987). Veteran stuntman Victor Magnotta drowned while performing a car stunt in which he drove the vehicle off a Hoboken pier and plunged into the [[Hudson River]]. He was pinned in the car, and could not escape before drowning.<ref name="Stunt Safety">{{cite web |url=http://www.moviegunservices.com/mgs_stunt-safety.html |title=Stunt Safety |publisher=Movie Gun Services |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[The Untouchables (film)|The Untouchables]]'' (1987). While filming the first take of the scene when his character is riddled with bullets from [[Frank Nitti]] ([[Billy Drago]])'s tommy gun, [[Sean Connery]] caught dust in his eye and had to be hospitalized. Film director [[Brian De Palma]] recalled having to beg Connery to do a second take of the scene.<ref name=klimek>{{cite web|last=Klimek|first=Chris|title='De Palma': An Underrated Director Opens Up About His Work, And His Obsessions|date=9 June 2016|publisher=[[NPR]]|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/06/09/481000877/de-palma-an-underrated-director-opens-up-about-his-work-and-his-obsessions|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref><ref name=newman>{{cite web|last=Newman|first=Jason|title=15 Things We Learned From the 'De Palma' Documentary|date=9 June 2016|publisher=''[[Rolling Stone]]''|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/15-things-we-learned-from-the-de-palma-documentary-20160609|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> *''[[Braddock: Missing in Action III]]'' (1988). On location in the [[Philippines]], a helicopter hired by the [[Cannon Group]] crashed into [[Manila Bay]], killing four Filipino soldiers (who were working as extras) and wounding five other people on the ground. This helicopter accident occurred the same day the "not guilty" ''Twilight Zone'' verdict was handed down in a Los Angeles Superior Court.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''[[Die Hard]]'' (1988). [[Bruce Willis]] lost two-thirds of his hearing after firing a gun loaded with extra loud blanks from underneath a table.<ref name="ScreenSlam">{{cite web|url=http://www.screenslam.com/10-star-actors-badly-injured-on-movie-sets/|title=10 Star Actors Who Were Badly Injured on Movie Sets|author=Cauthen, Shawn|date=15 March 2013|publisher=''Screen Slam''|accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref> *''[[Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers]]'' (1988). While filming a rooftop scene, [[Ellie Cornell]] accidentally slipped and her torso was cut by a large nail. She lost a large amount of blood but recovered, going on to continue on with the film.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} *''[[Red Heat (1988 film)|Red Heat]]'' (1988). Stuntman and director [[Bennie Dobbins]] suffered a fatal heart attack while filming a fight scene in freezing conditions outdoors in Austria. The scene required [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] and another actor to fight near-naked in deep snow. Dobbins over-exerted himself trying to install fan heaters in the snow to prevent the actors suffering hypothermia.<ref>Freese, Gene Scott. ''Hollywood Stunt Performers: 1910s-1970s''. MacFarlane & Company Inc. 2014. p1846</ref> *''[[Back to the Future Part II]]'' (1989). During a "[[hoverboard]]" stunt scene, stuntwoman [[Cheryl Wheeler-Dixon]] was accidentally bounced off a pillar before falling thirty feet onto concrete, sustaining serious facial and wrist injuries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://io9.gizmodo.com/the-hoverboard-scene-in-back-to-the-future-2-nearly-kil-1713294885 |title=The Hoverboard Scene In ''Back To The Future 2'' Nearly Killed A Stuntwoman |author=Anders, Charlie Jane |publisher=[[Io9]]/[[Gizmodo]] |date=23 June 2015 |accessdate=7 February 2016}}</ref> *''[[Cyborg (film)|Cyborg]]'' (1989). While filming, Jackson "Rock" Pinckney lost his eye during filming when [[Jean-Claude Van Damme]] accidentally struck his eye with a prop knife. Pinckney sued Van Damme in a [[North Carolina]] court and was awarded $487,500.<ref>{{cite web | title= Bodybuilder Wins $487,500 For Injury By Van Damme |work= [[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=|url= http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1993-02-27/news/9302260751_1_damme-jean-claude-van-cyborg|accessdate=2011-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P9ADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&lpg=PA18 |title=The Trial of Jean-Claude Van Damme |author=Lindow, Thomas W. |work=[[Black Belt (magazine)|Black Belt]] via Google Books |accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> *''[[H. B. Halicki#Marriage, the 1989 reboot of Gone In 60 Seconds 2 and death|Gone in 60 Seconds 2]]'' (1989, unfinished). Director/actor [[H. B. Halicki]] was killed in [[Buffalo, New York]], when a water tower he was planning to topple fell prematurely, hitting a telephone pole that then struck him in the head. The film was scrapped as a result of the accident.<ref name="Los Angeles Times">{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-12-20/local/me-16096_1_movie-sets |title=Deaths on Movie Sets |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=20 December 1995 |accessdate=21 December 2012}}</ref> *''Hired to Kill'' (1989). Stuntman Clint Carpenter was killed and three others and the pilot were injured in a helicopter crash in Corfu, Greece.<ref name="Brown2010">{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Len|title=Jason Statham|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WqP2eH-eB30C&pg=PT44|accessdate=4 May 2012|date=23 December 2010|publisher=Orion|isbn=978-1-4091-3266-0|page=44}}</ref> *''[[The Karate Kid Part III]]'' (1989). Actor [[Sean Kanan]] suffered internal bleeding after doing 20 takes of being thrown out a door and landing on his stomach. He collapsed at a Las Vegas hotel four days after shooting the scene and was discovered to have two quarts of blood pooled in his abdomen.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://people.com/archive/critically-injured-in-filming-karate-kid-bad-boy-sean-kanan-rallies-to-fight-to-the-finish-vol-32-no-3/ |title=Critically Injured in Filming, Karate Kid Bad Boy Sean Kanan Rallies to Fight to the Finish |author=Cunneff, Tom |publisher=''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' |date=17 July 1989 |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> *''[[The Return of the Musketeers]]'' (1989). On 20 September 1988, [[Roy Kinnear]] suffered a broken pelvis in a horseback riding accident and died of a heart attack the following day.<ref name="World's Strangest"/><ref name="nine"/><ref name="Churcher2011">{{cite book|last=Churcher|first=Mel|title=Acting For Film|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q3_ImUgAfZoC&pg=PT242|accessdate=4 May 2012|date=8 June 2011|publisher=Ebury Publishing|isbn=978-0-7535-4746-5|page=242}}</ref> *''[[The Sword of Tipu Sultan]]'' (1989). The largest number of on-set deaths in film history took place during the filming of this Indian made-for-TV movie. A total of 62 extras and crew members died after a fire broke out and they were trapped inside the burning film studio. Director and star [[Sanjay Khan]] suffered major burns and spent 13 months in hospital undergoing 72 surgeries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/studio-fire-during-shooting-of-tele-serial-the-sword-of-tipu-sultan-kills-more-than-40/1/323127.html |title=A gory mishap |author=Rajghatta, Chidanand |publisher=''[[India Today]]'' |date=28 February 1989 |accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref>
==1990s==
*''[[Back to the Future Part III]]'' (1990). In the scene where [[List of Back to the Future characters#Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen|Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen]] and his gang roped and hanged [[Marty McFly]], [[Michael J. Fox]] lost consciousness for a few seconds from being hanged before an extra realized he was legitimately being asphyxiated and the noose was lowered. He recorded this event in his autobiography, ''Lucky Man''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thefilmbox.org/ultimate-facts/ultimate-facts-back-to-the-future-part-iii/2/|title=Ultimate Facts: Back to the Future Part III - Page 2 of 3 - The Film Box|date=2015-06-26|work=The Film Box|access-date=2018-03-18|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="Cracked"/> *''[[Delta Force 2: The Colombian Connection]]'' (1990). Five people were killed in a helicopter crash during filming in the [[Philippines]].<ref name="World's Strangest"/><ref name="Los Angeles Times"/> The fatalities here were: Jojo Imperiale (pilot), Geoff Brewer (actor), Gadi Danzig (cameraman), Mike Graham (key grip) and Don Marshall (gaffer).<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref name="Deadline Hollywood 2"/> *''[[Bikini Island (film)|Bikini Island]]'' (1991). Stuntman Jay C. Currin was killed the first day of filming when a stunt fall off a 55-foot cliff went wrong and he landed on some rocks instead of the airbag that had been placed to break his fall.<ref name="World's Strangest">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsstrangest.com/mental-floss/the-quick-10-10-film-set-tragedies/|title=The Quick 10|publisher=World's Strangest|accessdate=21 December 2012}}</ref> *''[[Highlander II: The Quickening]]'' (1991). [[Christopher Lambert]] and [[Michael Ironside]] both suffered injuries during filming. Lambert chipped one of Ironside's teeth during a fight scene, while Ironside inadvertently chopped off part of Lambert's finger during a sword fight scene.<ref>{{cite news |title=The pain of realism |first=Thomas D. |last=Elias |agency=Scripps Howard News Service |publisher=Independent Press |date=25 October 1991 |work=St. Petersburg Times |page=4D |issn=1563-6291}}</ref> *''[[Terminator 2: Judgment Day]]'' (1991). [[Linda Hamilton]] suffered permanent hearing damage in one ear during filming when she fired a gun inside an elevator without using her ear plugs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/bbsitecontent/editorial/promotions/may10/linda-hamilton.aspx |title=Linda Hamilton: Interview |author=Julius, Marshall |publisher=[[Blockbuster LLC|Blockbuster UK]] |accessdate=1 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025062335/http://www.blockbuster.co.uk/bbsitecontent/editorial/promotions/may10/linda-hamilton.aspx |archivedate=25 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> She also injured her knees from falling on the ground during multiple re-shoots of her character being hit with a nightstick by actor Ken Gibbel. Frustrated by Gibbel's refusal to hit her properly, Hamilton legitimately knocked him out with a broom handle during the escape scene.<ref name="Missed">{{cite web|url=http://whatculture.com/film/10-genuine-on-screen-acting-injuries-you-probably-missed?page=11|title=10 Genuine On-Screen Acting Injuries You Probably Missed|author=Gallagher, Simon|date=6 October 2013|publisher=''What Culture''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170110131109/http://whatculture.com/film/10-genuine-on-screen-acting-injuries-you-probably-missed?page=11|archivedate=10 January 2017|deadurl=yes|accessdate=14 June 2014|df=}}</ref> [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] nearly broke some fingers while twirling his shotgun with one hand. While there was a shotgun with a lever loop lengthened to fit Schwarzenegger's hand, he mistakenly picked up a standard sized unit and injured his hand while attempting the stunt.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.factfiend.com/schwarzenegger-nearly-broke-fingers-filming-terminator-2/ |title=How Schwarzenegger Nearly Broke His Fingers Filming ''Terminator 2'' |author=Smallwood, Karl |publisher=FactFiend.com |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> *''[[The Bodyguard (1992 film)|The Bodyguard]]'' (1992). A worker died when he was crushed between two lighting equipment cranes during filming.<ref name="Los Angeles Times"/> * [[Wind (film)|''Wind'']] (1992). Australian stuntman Chris Anderson had to have a leg amputated below the knee after he was severely injured when a 30-foot yacht collided with the jet-boat on which Anderson was eating his lunch during a break in filming.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cargraphics.com.au/car-graphics-articles/1998/4/12/falling-stars/ |title=Falling Stars |author=Schwartz, Larry |publisher=''Car Graphics'' |date=12 April 1998 |accessdate=27 May 2014}}</ref> *''[[999 (UK TV series)|999]]'' (1993). While recreating a real life near-fatal parachute incident in which a parachutist tangled his equipment with the aircraft's landing gear before freeing himself, veteran stuntman [[Tip Tipping]] leapt out of a [[Cessna]] and crashed into woods near [[Ellingham, Northumberland]], he was pronounced dead when medical staff arrived.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/stuntman-killed-in-parachute-jump-1471168.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Stuntman killed in parachute jump | date=6 February 1993}}</ref> *''[[Crime Story (film)|Crime Story]]'' (1993). Jackie Chan's legs were crushed between two cars during a dangerous stunt scene.<ref name="I Am Jackie Chan"/> * ''[[The Fugitive (1993 film)|The Fugitive]]'' (1993). [[Harrison Ford]] damaged some ligaments on his leg while filming a chase scene in the woods. Because he refused to have surgery until filming was wrapped, his character Dr. Richard Kimble walked with a limp throughout the film.<ref name="Harrison Ford"/> * ''[[Gettysburg (1993 film)|Gettysburg]]'' (1993). During filming of the battle scenes on [[Little Round Top]], Bradley Egen, an extra playing a Union soldier, was unintentionally struck in the head by the butt of a musket and suffered a severe concussion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.americanhistory.si.edu/osaycanyousee/2012/10/part-ii-my-experience-on-the-set-of-gettysburg.html |title=Part II: My Experience on the set of "Gettysburg" |author=Egen, Brian James |publisher=Smithsonian National Museum of American History |date=19 October 2012 |accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref> *''[[Sliver (film)|Sliver]]'' (1993). Cameraman Michael Benson suffered lung injuries after a helicopter crash left him trapped for two days inside a Hawaiian volcano crater. The crew aboard the helicopter was flying over an active volcano to shoot the film's original opening sequence, but the footage was lost in the crash.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://articles.latimes.com/1992-11-25/local/me-933_1_woodland-hills | location=Hawaii | work=LA Times | title= Cameraman Stars in Volcano Ordeal : Rescue: Woodland Hills resident is recovering after spending two days trapped in a Hawaiian crater. | date=27 November 1992 | accessdate=26 February 2014 | first=Patrice | last=Apodaca}}</ref> *''[[The Crow (1994 film)|The Crow]]'' (1994). On 31 March 1993, American actor and martial artist [[Brandon Lee]] was accidentally shot and killed in [[North Carolina]] with a [[.44 magnum]] gun that was intended to fire blanks but contained a bullet left behind after a dummy round had been inserted and removed.<ref name="Huffington"/><ref name="HowStuffWorks"/><ref name="World's Strangest"/><ref name="Los Angeles Times"/><ref name="Schanie2010">{{cite book|last=Schanie|first=Andrew|title=Movie Confidential: Sex, Scandal, Murder and Mayhem in the Film Industry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rYfoLmaa3I4C&pg=PA179|accessdate=4 May 2012|date=1 June 2010|publisher=Clerisy Press|isbn=978-1-57860-354-1|page=179}}</ref> Also, on 1 February 1993 on the opening day of filming a carpenter was severely shocked and burned when his scissor lift struck power lines.<ref name="nine"/> * ''[[Seven (1995 film)|Seven]]'' (1995). In a scene where Detective David Mills ([[Brad Pitt]]) chased John Doe in the rain, Pitt fell and his arm went through a car windscreen, requiring surgery. This accident was written into the script to explain Pitt wearing a cast over his arm. Coincidentally, the original script did call for Pitt's character to be injured during this sequence but not to his hand.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/SHOWBIZ/Movies/9509/seven/ |title="Seven"-- Deadly cinema? |author=Buckland, Carol |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=23 September 1995 |accessdate=19 December 2013}}</ref> *''[[Vampire in Brooklyn]]'' (1995). [[Angela Bassett]]'s stunt double Sonja Davis fell to her death in a stunt gone wrong.<ref name="Brown2010"/> Her death led to a $50 million wrongful-death lawsuit against [[Paramount Pictures]].<ref name="Joshi2010">{{cite book|last=Joshi|first=S. T.|title=Encyclopedia of the Vampire: The Living Dead in Myth, Legend, and Popular Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RSNq99Oa310C&pg=PA346|accessdate=4 May 2012|date=4 November 2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-37833-1|page=346}}</ref> *''[[Waterworld]]'' (1995). During production, actresses [[Jeanne Tripplehorn]] and [[Tina Majorino]] were thrown overboard from the [[trimaran]] they were on when its bowsprit snapped. Nearly a dozen rescue divers jumped in and brought them back on board. [[Kevin Costner]] nearly died when he was caught in a squall while tied to the mast of his trimaran. In addition, several cast and crew members suffered from seasickness and jellyfish stings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20100733,00.html |title= Kevin Costner's Hawaii Uh-Oh |author=Levitt, Shelley |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=29 May 1995 |accessdate=19 January 2016}}</ref> Costner's stunt double, Laird Hamilton, was lost at sea for a few hours when his jet ski ran out of fuel after the filming of a jet ski scene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.warpedfactor.com/2015/07/1995-trouble-with-waterworld.html?m=1 |title=1995 - The Trouble With WATERWORLD |publisher=Warped Factor |date=29 July 2015 |accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref> * ''Ah Kam'' (1996). On October 1995, actress [[Michelle Yeoh]], who usually performs her own stunts, was seriously injured during shooting of the film about the life of a stuntwoman, when she misjudged an {{convert|18|ft|m|adj=on}} jump off a bridge onto a truck. She fractured a vertebra and was in traction for a month. The sequence can be seen at the end of the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lovehkfilm.com/reviews/ah_kam.htm|title=The Stuntwoman|work=Lovehkfilm.com|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Black & Decker]] commercial (1996). Veteran pilot Michael Tamburro died after suffering a broken neck and head injuries in a helicopter crash caused by hitting a main rotor blade on a rock on the side of a desert butte. Co-pilot [[Alan Purwin]] suffered a broken arm, and flying debris from the crash injured a crew member. Producers [[Propaganda Films]] had not obtained a permit to use a helicopter when filming, which the firm claimed was due to an unintentional oversight.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SHIFT+IN+COPTER%27S+APPROACH+STUDIED+IN+FATAL+CRASH+%3A+PROBE+ALSO...-a083963445|title=Shift in copter's approach studied in fatal crash : Probe also targets firm's failure to file film permit|accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref> *''[[Love Serenade]]'' (1996). During the filming of a scene on a [[grain silo]], stuntman Collin Dragsbaek (doubling actor George Shetsov) died when he fell onto a faulty airbag.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/entertainment/film/when-actors-drop-dead/2009/10/26/1256405349835.html |title=What directors do when actors drop dead |author=Molitorisz, Sacha |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=27 October 2009 |accessdate=27 May 2014}}</ref> * ''[[Gone Fishin' (film)|Gone Fishin']]'' (1997). Janet Wilder was killed and four other people, including her husband, were injured when a speedboat driver misjudged a ramp and the speedboat landed in a crowd.<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman Killed in Film Stunt : Accident: Woodland Hills resident was with her stuntman husband when she was struck by a boat.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-12-20/local/me-16074_1_woodland-hills|publisher=''LA Times'' | date=20 December 1995}}</ref> *''[[Pleasantville (film)|Pleasantville]]'' (1997). Cameraman Brent Hershman died when he fell asleep driving home after a 19-hour workday on the set of the film. Hershman's death resulted in a wrongful death suit, claiming that New Line Cinema, New Line Productions and Juno Pix Inc. were responsible for the death as a result of the lengthy work hours imposed on the set, and spurred a call to limit filming hours.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.vulture.com/2012/05/how-long-are-the-days-on-a-movie-set-polone.html | title=Polone: The Unglamorous, Punishing Hours of Working on a Hollywood Set | work=Vulture | date=May 23, 2012 | accessdate=August 6, 2013 |last1=Polone |first1=Gavin |authorlink1=Gavin Polone}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/dec/21/local/me-995 | title=Death After Long Workday Spurs Suit | work=Los Angeles Times | date=December 21, 1997 | accessdate=August 6, 2013 |last1=O'Neill |first1=Ann W.}}</ref> *''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'' (1997). Several extras were injured during the film's climactic sinking scene where passengers fell and hit parts of the ship. Injuries ranged from a broken ankle to cracked ribs, a fractured cheekbone, and a ruptured spleen.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sabotagetimes.com/reportage/james-cameron-and-the-incredible-untold-story-behind-titanic/ |title=James Cameron and The Incredible Untold Story Behind Titanic |author=Luck, Richard |publisher=''Sabotage Times'' |date=26 March 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> [[Kate Winslet]] suffered pneumonia from filming the water scenes after she refused to wear a wetsuit under her dress. During the scene where Jack and Rose were running away from an ocean wave in the hallways, Winslet's coat snagged on a gate, pulling her down and nearly drowning her.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ivillage.com/kate-winslet-titanic-near-death-experience/1-a-65864 |title=Kate Winslet's Near-Death Experience During 'Titanic' |author=Kaufman, Donna |publisher=[[iVillage]] |date=13 November 2009 |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> On the final night of shooting in [[Nova Scotia]], 80 cast and crew members were hospitalized after pranksters spiked the clam chowder at the catering area with [[Phencyclidine|PCP]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mjs538/things-you-didnt-know-about-titanic |title=33 Things You Didn't Know About the Movie ''Titanic'' |author=Stopera, Matt |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]] |date=31 March 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> *''[[Blues Brothers 2000]]'' (1998). While filming a stunt scene, a car rolled onto two crew members, one of whom needed a leg amputation. Three months later, during filming for a car crash sequence, stuntman Bob Minor suffered severe injuries to his head.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Artists/A/Aykroyd_Dan/1997/10/22/756444.html |title=Blues Brothers mishaps spark second probe |publisher=''Canoe.ca'' |accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> *''Galápagos: The Enchanted Voyage'' (1998). Noel Archambault, the film's camera operator/stereographer, was killed in an ultralight aircraft crash along with the pilot, William Raisner Jr., while filming in the [[Galápagos Islands]]. The men were found at an elevation of 3,000 feet on [[Cerro Azul (Ecuador volcano)|Cerro Azul]], one of the two most active volcanoes in the archipelago.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/1998/film/news/cameraman-dies-in-crash-1117478104/ |title=Cameraman dies in crash |publisher="Variety" |date=2 July 1998 |accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref> *''[[Mighty Joe Young (1998 film)|Mighty Joe Young]]'' (1998). Director of photography Don Peterman and camera operator Ray de la Motte were injured while preparing a crane shot in July 1997 in [[Thousand Oaks, California]]. Both suffered extensive neck and head injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/34798/two-hurt-on-mighty-joe-young-shoot |title=Two Hurt on "Mighty Joe Young" Shoot |work=Eonline.com |accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref>
==2000s== *''[[Cast Away]]'' (2000). While filming, [[Tom Hanks]] cut his leg. Two weeks later, the swelling on his leg persisted, and Hanks was confined to a hospital for three weeks to treat a [[Staphylococcus|staph infection]] that would have killed him from blood poisoning.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinemablend.com/pop/Hanks-Almost-Died-While-Filming-Castaway-7381.html |title=Hanks Almost Died While Filming ''Cast Away'' |author=Celeb Staink |publisher=CinemaBlend |accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> *''[[Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon]]'' (2000). During a fight scene, [[Michelle Yeoh]] tore an [[Anterior cruciate ligament|ACL]] on her knee after a bad landing and had to be flown from China to [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]] in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], for surgery.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/health/spotlight/2001-04-16-yeoh-knee.htm |title=''Crouching Tiger'' Star Earns Stripes After Knee Injury |author=Morgan, John |work=[[USA Today]] |date=16 April 2001 |accessdate=14 April 2017}}</ref> *''[[Dinosaur (film)|Dinosaur]]'' (2000). A crew member was killed and another seriously wounded when a camera boom struck a cross-country power line.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/feb/28/local/me-23933 | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |title=Boom's Counterweight Cited as Possible Cause of Fatal Accident |date=28 February 1998 |accessdate=26 February 2014 |first=Andrew |last=Blankstein}}</ref> * ''[[Proof of Life]]'' (2000). [[David Morse (actor)|David Morse]]'s stand-in, Will Gaffney, was killed while riding on truck that drove off a mountain road.<ref>{{cite web|title=10 April 2000|publisher=[[ABC News]]|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=106910&page=1|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Dana|title=Stand-in killed as truck drives off cliff|date=11 April 2000|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)]]''|url=https://variety.com/2000/film/news/stand-in-killed-as-truck-drives-off-cliff-1117780422/|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Jensen|first=Jeff|title=The making of ''Proof of Life''|date=15 December 2000|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|url=http://ew.com/article/2000/12/15/making-proof-life/|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref> * ''[[Taxi 2]]'' (2000). A [[Peugeot 406]] was supposed to land in a pile of cardboard after a stunt, but missed and hit several crew. Cameraman Alain Dutartre died later of internal injuries while his assistant Jean-Michel Bar broke both legs.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2026403.stm |title=Besson investigated for film death |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=5 June 2002 |accessdate=23 December 2012}}</ref> *''[[Exit Wounds]]'' (2001). During filming in [[Hamilton, Ontario]], a van was being towed along a street upside-down as part of a chase scene; stuntman Chris Lamon and another man were supposed to roll safely out, but Lamon struck his head, and died six days later.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,280508,00.html |title=Tragic Show |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=30 May 2001 |accessdate=20 January 2014 |first=Jeff |last=Jensen}}</ref> *''[[Pearl Harbor (film)|Pearl Harbor]]'' (2001). A stunt plane dressed like a Japanese fighter crashed during a flight over the movie set. The pilot survived the crash escaping serious injuries.<ref name="Honolulu Star-Bulletin"/><ref>{{cite news |title='Pearl Harbor' Stunt Flier Injured In Honolulu Crash |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2000-04-19/news/0004190100_1_crash-honolulu-flying-experience |newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |date=19 April 2000 |accessdate=18 December 2012}}</ref> *''[[:ru:Связной (фильм, 2002)|The Messenger]]'' (2002). Russian actor and director [[Sergei Bodrov, Jr.]] and 42 film crew members were killed in the [[Kolka-Karmadon rock ice slide]] after finishing the second day of shooting on 20 September.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2280434.stm |title=Sergei Bodrov: Russia's lost actor |publisher=BBC |date=25 September 2002 |accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> *''[[XXX (2002 film)|XXX]]'' (2002). [[Vin Diesel]]'s stunt double, [[Harry L. O'Connor]], was killed during filming,<ref name="Brown2010"/> in a scene in which he was supposed to rappel down a parasailing line and land on a submarine but struck a bridge at high speed and was killed instantly.<ref name="World's Strangest"/><ref name="nine"/> *''[[Ripley's Believe It or Not! (TV series)|Ripley's Believe It or Not!]]'' (2003). While filming an episode near [[Kingman, Arizona]], a filming helicopter flew into a power line. David Gibbs, the helicopter pilot, had his pilot's license suspended for the accident. He would later on be involved in another helicopter accident in 2013 that killed him and two passengers.<ref name="Verrier"/> *''[[CrossBones (film)|CrossBones]]'' (2004). Cinematographer [[Neal Fredericks]] was killed when the Cessna from which he was filming crashed near the Dry Tortugas off the coast of Florida on 14 August 2004. Although the director, pilot, and two other crew members were able to escape, Fredericks could not free himself from his harness and drowned.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/aug/21/local/me-passings21.4 |title=Neal Fredericks, 35; Was Cinematographer on 'The Blair Witch Project' |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=21 August 2004 |accessdate=1 March 2014}}</ref> *''[[Kill Bill: Volume 2]]'' (2004). While filming a driving scene in Mexico, [[Uma Thurman]] sustained a concussion and injured her knees when she lost control of the car and crashed into a palm tree.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/kill-bill-uma-thurman-quentin-tarantino-stunt-coordinator-stunts-car-crash-a8209331.html |title=Kill Bill stunt coordinator on Uma Thurman's accident: 'No stunts were scheduled for the day' |author=Kaplan, Ilana |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |date=13 February 2018 |accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref> *''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'' (2004). In playing the role of [[Jesus Christ]], [[Jim Caviezel]] sustained gashes to his back from multiple whippings, hypothermia, and a separated shoulder from carrying a giant cross. He was also struck by lightning before filming the [[Sermon of the Mount]] scene.<ref name="Mandatory"/> *''[[The Phantom of the Opera (2004 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' (2004). A worker suffered severe injuries when he was thrown from scaffolding that was not properly secured on the set of the film. Actor [[Patrick Wilson (American actor)|Patrick Wilson]] fell off his horse approximately three times while filming his own stunt scene at riding the horse bareback. He also nearly drowned while filming the water scenes in the lake.<ref name="Huffington"/> *''[[Troy (film)|Troy]]'' (2004). [[Brad Pitt]], who played Achilles in the film, tore his left [[Achilles tendon]] during production.<ref name="Huffington"/> George Camilleri, a bodybuilding extra, broke his leg while filming an action sequence at [[Għajn Tuffieħa]]. He was operated on the following day but suffered complications and died two weeks later.<ref name="nine"/> *''[[Æon Flux (film)|Æon Flux]]'' (2005). [[Charlize Theron]] was performing backflips during filming and landed on her neck, herniating a disc close to her spinal cord. Production was shut down for eight weeks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2012/01/03/no_more_stunt_work_for_charlize_theron |title=No More Stunt Work for Charlize Theron |publisher=''StarPulse'' |date=3 January 2012 |accessdate=20 December 2012}}</ref> *''[[Syriana]]'' (2005). During a torture scene where he was tied to a chair, [[George Clooney]] suffered head and spinal injuries and memory loss when he hit his head on the floor after the torturer knocked his chair over. The impact ruptured his [[dura mater]], resulting in loss of [[cerebrospinal fluid]]. The injury was so painful that he contemplated committing suicide while recovering.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2059563/George-Clooney-I-considered-suicide-agonising-spinal-injury.html |title=I thought, 'I can't exist like this': George Clooney reveals how he contemplated suicide after agonising spinal injury |author=Bates, Daniel |work=[[The Daily Mail]] |date=10 November 2011 |accessdate=14 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/oct/23/film.usa |title=Head injury drove Clooney to think of suicide |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=23 October 2005 |accessdate=14 April 2017}}</ref> *''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]'' (2006). While filming the [[Madagascar]] fight scene in [[Barbados]], [[Daniel Craig]] knocked out two of his front teeth. The damage was so severe that Craig's dentist had to be flown in from London to fix caps into his mouth.<ref name="Craig">{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3286986/Being-007-left-battered-need-knee-op-says-Daniel-Craig-reveals-injured-filming-Spectre-fight-scene.html |title=Being 007 has left me so battered I need a knee op, says Daniel Craig as he reveals he injured himself filming ''Spectre'' fight scene |author=Creighton, Sam |work=[[The Daily Mail]] |date=23 October 2015 |accessdate=14 April 2017}}</ref> *''[[Jackass Number Two]]'' (2006). During filming of the closing scene [[Ryan Dunn]] was performing a stunt with [[Bam Margera]] in which both of them are pulled out of shot by a running horse by a rope tied around their feet. Dunn dropped straight onto his shoulder, causing damage to the muscles and leading to a life-threatening blood clot near his heart and brain.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} *''[[Ocean's Deadliest]]'' (2006). On 4 September 2006, [[Steve Irwin]] was fatally pierced in the chest by a [[stingray]] spine while snorkelling at the [[Great Barrier Reef]], at [[Batt Reef]], which is located off the coast of [[Port Douglas, Queensland|Port Douglas]] in north [[Queensland]]. Irwin was in the area filming the documentary, but weather had stalled filming. He decided to take the opportunity to film some shallow water shots for a segment in the television program his daughter Bindi was hosting when the ray suddenly turned and lashed out at him with the spine on its tail.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2006/09/060905-irwin.html |title="Crocodile Hunter" Death Extremely Rare, Caught on Film |work=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |date=6 September 2006 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> *''Top Gear'' (2006). While filming a challenge for [[Top Gear (series 9)|Series 9 Episode 1]] in Yorkshire, [[Richard Hammond]] crashed a dragster at 288 mph, seriously injuring his brain.<ref name="Hammond" /> His front-right tire failed on the seventh run that caused him to hit the grass and roll the [[Vampire (car)|Vampire]] he was driving. During the roll, Hammond's helmet had embedded itself into the ground, flipping the visor up and forcing dirt into his mouth and left eye, damaging the eye. Rescuers felt a pulse and heard the unconscious Hammond breathing before the car was turned upright.<ref name="Hammond">{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/richard-hammond-on-his-brain-injury-and-shock-386102 |title=Richard Hammond on his brain injury and shock at Natasha Richardson's death |author=Neil, Beth |work=[[Daily Mirror]] |date=4 April 2009 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Hammond also hurt his neck in the "Cheap Car Challenge of " [[Top Gear (series 8)|Series 8 Episode 8]] when his [[Suzuki Carry#Eighth generation (1985–1991)|Suzuki Super Carry]] rolled over.<ref name="Top Gear">{{cite web|url=http://www.motoringbox.com/cars/entertainment/top-gear/top-gears-worst-injuries/|title=The ''Top Gear'' trio's worst injuries|author=McKellar, Sean|date=8 January 2015|publisher=''MotoringBox''|accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref> *''[[Wowowee]]'' (2006). A [[PhilSports Stadium stampede|stampede]] occurred at [[PhilSports Football and Athletics Stadium]], where the Philippine game show was filming its first anniversary episode. The stampede killed 73 people and injured 392 others.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4680040.stm |title=Manila stadium stampede kills 73 |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=4 February 2006 |accessdate=19 December 2012}}</ref> The incident is cited in the 2007 [[Guinness World Records]] as "the greatest death toll in a game show."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20080701-145684/Scoffed-at-lessons |title=Scoffed-at lessons |author=Mercado, Juan |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=1 July 2008 |accessdate=19 December 2012}}</ref> * ''Past Tense'' (2006). During the production of this [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] film, [[Gabrielle Carteris]] suffered from partial facial paralysis and a speech impediment from a scene where her character was choked and dragged down a flight of stairs by actor Adrian Hughes. She sued the film's producers for medical expenses, loss of earnings, and various damages.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.canadianhealthlaw.com/gabrielle-carteris-choking-suit/ |title=Gabrielle Carteris Choking Suit |publisher=Canadian Health Law |date=27 February 2012 |accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20184694,00.html |title='I Couldn't Move My Face' |author=Rizzo, Monica |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=17 March 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/gabrielle-carteris-opens-up-about-her-debilitating-injury_article_8776 |title=Gabrielle Carteris Opens Up About Her Debilitating Injury |work=[[Access Hollywood]] |date=14 March 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/gabrielle-carteris-sues-makers-of-film-claims-on-set-injury_article_8696 |title=Gabrielle Carteris Sues Makers of Film, Claims On-Set Injury |work=[[Access Hollywood]] |date=7 March 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref> *''[[Charlie Wilson's War (film)|Charlie Wilson's War]]'' (2007). A special effects assistant was critically injured when a prop missile exploded.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.moviefone.com/2007/01/19/crewman-seriously-injured-on-set-of-charlie-wilsons-war/ |title=Crewman Seriously Injured On Set of Charlie Wilson's War |author=Davis, Erik |publisher=[[Moviefone]] |date=19 January 2007 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> *''[[Fifth Gear]]'' (2007). During the filming of Series 12, episode 7,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fifthgear.five.tv/jsp/5gmain.jsp?lnk=450 |title=''Fifth Gear'': Behind the Scenes |publisher=[[Channel 5 (UK)|Five]] |accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> presenter [[Tom Ford (presenter)|Tom Ford]] broke his foot and several toes when he crashed a modified [[Bedford Rascal]] van while recording a piece about [[Drifting (motorsport)|drifting]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.autotrader.co.uk/EDITORIAL/CARS/news/36636.html |title=''Fifth Gear'' star Tom Ford hurt in crash |publisher=[[Auto Trader Group]] |accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> [[British Touring Car Championship|BTCC driver]] [[Jason Plato]] suffered multiple burns when a [[Caparo T1]] he was driving at [[Bruntingthorpe Aerodrome|Bruntingthorpe proving ground]] burst into flames.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crash.net/news_view~cid~10~id~155660.htm |title=Plato injured as Caparo T1 bursts into flames |publisher=Crash.net |accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> *''[[The Final Season]]'' (2007). Cameraman Roland Schlotzhauer was killed during filming when the helicopter he was on hit power lines and crashed into a field. The helicopter pilot and one of the film's producers were seriously injured.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref name="nine"/> *''[[Live Free or Die Hard]]'' (2007). [[Bruce Willis]] was injured during a fight scene when he was kicked above his right eye by [[Maggie Q]]'s stunt double, who was wearing stiletto heels. Willis was hospitalized and received seven stitches that ran through his right eyebrow and down into the corner of his eye.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah3717.shtml |title=Ain't That A Kick In The Head: Bruce Willis Injured |accessdate=3 October 2013|date=25 January 2007|work=[[Access Hollywood]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071119023724/http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah3717.shtml |archivedate = 19 November 2007}}</ref> Willis' stunt double [[Larry Rippenkroeger]] was knocked unconscious when he fell {{convert|25|ft|m}} from a fire escape to the pavement. Rippenkroeger suffered broken bones in his face, several broken ribs, a punctured lung, and fractures in both wrists. Due to his injuries, production was temporarily shut down. Willis personally paid the hotel bills for Rippenkroeger's parents and visited him a number of times at the hospital.<ref>{{cite news|last=Welkos |first=Robert W. |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/may/25/entertainment/et-stuntmen25 |title=Defying death for real |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/603n0UFE5?url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/may/25/entertainment/et-stuntmen25 |archivedate=9 July 2011 |date=25 May 2007 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *''[[The Dark Knight (film)|The Dark Knight]]'' (2008). Cameraman Conway Wickliffe was killed in 2007 on the set of ''The Dark Knight'', as he rode in a pickup truck driving parallel to a stunt car; the pickup missed a 90-degree turn and crashed into a tree.<ref name="Yahoo"/><ref name="World's Strangest"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Special effects expert cleared over death on set of The Dark Knight |author=Ben Child |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/mar/15/special-effects-expert-cleared-dark-knight |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=18 December 2012 |location=London}}</ref> * ''[[Jumper (2008 film)|Jumper]]'' (2008). Set dresser David Ritchie was crushed to death by frozen debris as an exterior set was being dismantled.<ref name="nine"/> * ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' (2008). While filming an action scene, [[Mariska Hargitay]] suffered a collapsed lung after landing wrongly, requiring multiple surgeries to correct the injury.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.redbookmag.com/life/friends-family/interviews/a5142/mariska-hargitay-interview/ |title=Mariska Hargitay Opens Up About Her Injury |author=Woodruff, Lee |publisher=''[[Redbook]]'' |date=14 July 2009 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> * ''[[Red Cliff (film)|Red Cliff]]'' (2008/2009). While filming a scene in which a small boat was set on fire and was to ram a larger boat, the fire spread quickly out of control, killing stuntman Lu Yanqing and injuring six others.<ref>[https://movies.yahoo.com/mv/news/ap/20080610/121311672000.html "Stuntman Killed on John Woo Film Set" AP via Yahoo News]</ref> * [[Valkyrie (film)|''Valkyrie'']] (2008). During filming, the side of a vintage truck detached as the vehicle turned a sharp corner, causing a number of extras on board to fall out. One man was seriously injured and 10 more suffered minor injuries. The extras involved later filed a lawsuit against the production.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/2620647/Tom-Cruises-film-Valkyrie-hit-by-6m-lawsuit-from-injured-extras.html |title=Tom Cruise's film Valkyrie hit by £6m lawsuit from injured extras |author=Hall, Allan |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=25 August 2008 |accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indielondon.co.uk/Film-Review/extras-injured-on-valkyrie-film-set |title=Extras injured on Valkyrie film set |publisher=''IndieLondon'' |accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref> * ''[[63rd Tony Awards]]'' (2009). After performing the opening number with his band [[Poison (American band)|Poison]], lead vocalist [[Bret Michaels]] was struck in the head by a descending set and knocked to the floor. He suffered a fractured nose and a split lip that required three stitches.<ref>Silverman, Stephen M. [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20283748,00.html "Bret Michaels Injured at the Tony Awards"], People.com, June 8, 2009</ref> Michaels subsequently sued the event's organizers, claiming that the collision led to his 2010 brain hemorrhage. The suit was settled in May 2012 for an undisclosed amount.<ref>{{cite news|last=D'Zurilla|first=Christie|title=Bret Michaels, Tony Awards settle lawsuit over 2009 injuries|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/gossip/la-et-mg-bret-michaels-settlement-tony-awards,0,2599868.story|accessdate=24 December 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=15 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Gearty|first=Robert|title=Poison singer Bret Michaels to settle lawsuit over accident at 2009 Tony Awards|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/poison-singer-bret-michaels-settle-lawsuit-accident-2009-tony-awards-article-1.1078286#ixzz1ux1VANhU|accessdate=24 December 2015|location=New York|work=[[New York Daily News]]}}</ref> * ''[[G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra]]'' (2009). During an explosion effects misfire, [[Sienna Miller]]'s suit caught fire, igniting the area between her breasts.<ref name="Mandatory"/><ref name="News.com.au"/> * ''[[Inglourious Basterds]]'' (2009). In the scene where [[Hans Landa]] ([[Christoph Waltz]]) strangled Bridget Von Hammersmark ([[Diane Kruger]]) to death, director [[Quentin Tarantino]] stood in as Waltz's body double to give the scene more realism. Consequently, Kruger briefly lost consciousness from being strangled by Tarantino.<ref name="Cracked"/> * ''[[Nitro Circus]]'' (2009). [[Johnny Knoxville]] was attempting to do a back flip on a Moto X bike. He was halfway into the rotation when disaster struck. He bailed, he hit the ground hard and the bike landed on top of him. The handlebars hit his crotch, leaving him with serious genitalia injuries (tearing his urethra). As a result, he has to flush his bladder periodically by means of a [[Catheter]]. Knoxville said the process prevented [[Granulation tissue|scar tissue]] from forming.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news09/2-2.htm#wed |title=Stern Show News – Archive |work=MarksFriggin.com |date= |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Motocross racer [[Jolene Van Vugt]] broke her wrist after coming short of a 65-foot triple jump. She needed a metal plate attached with seven screws on her wrist and had to wear an arm cast throughout the second season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maxim.com/tv/jolene-van-vugt-the-bad-girl-of-nitro-circus |title=Jolene Van Vugt: The Bad Girl of 'Nitro Circus' |author=Thompson, Jesse |work=[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]] |date=25 August 2009 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> *''[[The Tournament (2009 film)|The Tournament]]'' (2009). In a botched attempt to turn over a semi-trailer truck with an air cannon for a chase scene, a piece of iron debris flew toward the production crew and hit assistant director Shero Rauf. Rauf broke both legs in that accident, which took him almost two years to walk normally again.<ref>{{cite video |people=Rauf, Shero |date=4 April 2011 |title=Shero Rauf 's Accident while making the movie ( The Tournament ) in Bulgaria |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ZmHGUyAp4E |medium= |language=Bulgarian |trans_title= |publisher=[[YouTube]] |location=Bulgaria |accessdate=27 September 2013 |time= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref>
==2010s==
* ''[[The Expendables (2010 film)|The Expendables]]'' (2010). [[Sylvester Stallone]] injured his neck while filming a fight scene with [[Stone Cold Steve Austin|Steve Austin]]. He required a metal plate inserted into his neck during surgery.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8443066.stm |title=Sylvester Stallone injures neck in fight scenes |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=6 January 2010 |accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="News.com.au"/> * ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (film)|Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]'' (2010/2011). During production at [[Leavesden Film Studios|Leavesden]], [[Daniel Radcliffe]]'s stunt double [[David Holmes (actor)|David Holmes]] suffered a serious spinal injury during the filming of an aerial sequence, which left him a [[tetraplegic]]. Holmes fell to the ground following an explosion that was part of the stunt.<ref name="News.com.au"/><ref>{{cite web|author=MuggleNet |url=http://www.mugglenet.com/app/news/full_story/2134 |title=The ULTIMATE Harry Potter Fansite – Deathly Hallows, Half-Blood Prince, JK Rowling, and much more |publisher=MuggleNet |date=29 January 2009 |accessdate=9 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=MuggleNet |url=http://mugglenet.com/app/news/full_story/2142 |title=The ULTIMATE Harry Potter Fansite – Deathly Hallows, Half-Blood Prince, JK Rowling, and much more |publisher=MuggleNet |accessdate=9 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Cockcroft |first=Lucy |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4420403/Harry-Potter-stuntman-David-Holmes-vows-to-return-to-work.html |title=Harry Potter stuntman David Holmes vows to return to work |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=1 February 2009 |accessdate=9 December 2009 }}</ref> * ''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]'' (2010). While filming a fight scene for the series finale "[[The End (Lost)|The End]]", [[Terry O'Quinn]] mistakenly stabbed [[Matthew Fox]] with a real knife instead of a collapsible one. Fox's life was saved by the kevlar vest underneath his shirt.<ref name="Whatculture">{{cite web |url=http://whatculture.com/tv/13-actors-who-almost-died-filming-major-tv-shows |title=13 Actors Who Almost Died Filming Major TV Shows - 12. Matthew Fox |author=Gallagher, Simon |publisher=Whatculture |date=27 April 2014 |accessdate=18 January 2018}}</ref> * ''[[Wetten, dass..?]]'' (2010). In the December 4 episode of this German entertainment series, stuntman Samuel Koch attempted to [[Powerbocking|powerbock]] over five moving cars in succession when his head hit the windshield of the fourth car (driven by his father), causing him to crash to the ground head-first, fracturing two vertebrae and rendering him [[Tetraplegia|quadriplegic]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1335851/Samuel-Koch-stunt-Student-seriously-injured-stilts-jump-moving-cars-live-TV.html |title=Stunt jumper student seriously injured after leaping over moving cars on spring stilts on live TV |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=6 December 2010 |accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Campus PD]]'' (2011). Cameraman Greg Jacobsen was killed in a helicopter crash while filming at the [[Indiana University of Pennsylvania]].<ref name="Yahoo"/> * ''[[The Eagle (2011 film)|The Eagle]]'' (2011). When filming in a freezing river, actors have a mixture of boiling hot water and river water poured down their suits to stay warm. A crew member forgot to mix the hot water with the river water during filming; as a result, [[Channing Tatum]] was scalded with boiling water that burned the skin off the tip of his penis.<ref name="ScreenSlam"/><ref name="News.com.au"/> * ''[[The Hangover Part II]]'' (2011). Australian stuntman Scott McLean suffered critical brain damage while filming in Bangkok after a taxi he was leaning out of the window of failed to dodge another vehicle, causing McLean's head to collide with it, "leaving him with a huge gash over the right side of his head and flesh torn from his skull".<ref name="DailyMail">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2032353/Hangover-2-stuntman-nearly-died-filming-taxi-scene-sues-Warner-Bros.html|title=''Hangover 2'' stuntman who nearly died filming taxi scene sues Warner Bros.|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=31 October 2012|location=London|first=Jade|last=Watkins|date=31 August 2011}}</ref> Warner Bros. then issued a statement stating McLean was put into a medically induced coma, and were reportedly paying his hospital bills.<ref name="DailyMail"/> McLean soon recovered, stating he had suffered "likely permanent brain and physical injuries" before suing the studio for unspecified damages.<ref name="News.com.au"/><ref name="DailyMail"/> * ''[[Transformers: Dark of the Moon]]'' (2011). An extra was seriously injured during a stunt in [[Hammond, Indiana]]. Due to a failed weld, a steel cable snapped from a car being towed and hit the extra's car, damaging her skull. The extra, identified as Gabriela Cédillo, had to undergo brain surgery.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jalopnik.com/5629380/extra-has-skull-sliced-open-on-transformers-3-set |title=Extra Has Skull "Sliced Open" On Transformers 3 Set|publisher=[[Jalopnik]]|date=3 September 2010|accessdate=20 August 2011}}</ref> The injury has left her permanently brain-damaged, paralyzed on her left side and her left eye stitched shut.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-10-05/news/ct-met-transformers-lawsuit-20101005_1_gabriela-cedillo-stunt-welding |title=Family of ''Transformers 3'' Extra Files Suit Over Accident |author=Eldeib, Duaa |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=5 October 2010 |accessdate=11 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11485712 |title=Paralysed Extra Sues Film Company |work=BBC News |date=6 October 2010 |accessdate=11 October 2010}}</ref> In May 2012, it was revealed that a $18 million settlement had been reached between Paramount and the Cedillo family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://transformerslive.blogspot.com/2012/05/18-million-settlement-for-transformers.html|title=$18 Million Settlement for Injured Transformers: DOTM Extra (Updated)|date=18 May 2010|accessdate=23 May 2010|publisher=TFW2005}}</ref> As a result of this accident, recycled footage from one of Michael Bay's previous movies, ''[[The Island (2005 film)|The Island]]'', was used instead with CG robots inserted into the footage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/spout/michael_bay_recycles |title=Why Did Michael Bay Recycle ''The Island'' Footage for ''Transformers: Dark of the Moon''? |author=Campbell, Christopher |publisher=[[Indiewire]] |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=8 May 2014}}</ref> *''[[Agneepath (2012 film)|Agneepath]]'' (2012). [[Hrithik Roshan]] suffered numerous injuries during production. He sustained burns on his hands when [[Priyanka Chopra]]'s [[Gagra choli|''lehenga'']] caught fire. He suffered an eye injury from ''[[Holi]]'' colors thrown to his face during a musical scene. He also sustained a major back injury from lifting a 110 kg man during an action scene.<ref name="MensXP"/> *''[[The Avengers (2012 film)|The Avengers]]'' (2012). While performing a 30-foot fall from a building, stuntman Jeremy Fitzgerald slammed into a pile of bricks and tore off a chunk of his scalp.<ref name="News.com.au">{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/movies/horrific-hollywood-movie-accidents/story-e6frfmvr-1226741038291 |title=Horrific Hollywood movie accidents |author=Rao, Shoba |publisher=News.com.au |date=16 October 2013 |accessdate=7 April 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Expendables 2]]'' (2012). While filming in [[Elin Pelin (town)|Elin Pelin]], [[Bulgaria]], a stuntman was killed and another was left in critical condition during a staged explosion on a rubber boat. The surviving stuntman underwent a five-hour operation that reportedly left him in stable condition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/10/stuntman-dies-during-the-filming-of-the-expendables-2/|title=UPDATE: Stuntmen In 'Expendables 2' Fatal Accident Identified|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> In addition, both Sylvester Stallone and [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] required shoulder surgery after filming.<ref name="ScreenSlam"/><ref name="News.com.au"/> * ''[[The Good Wife]]'' (2012). Kristin Chenoweth sustained a skull fracture, broken nose, spinal and rib injuries, and cracked teeth after a piece of the lighting rig fell on her, forcing her to require years of physical therapy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://people.com/tv/kristin-chenoweth-discusses-accident-and-medical-issues/ |title=Kristin Chenoweth Still Dealing with 'Pain and Issues' After ''Good Wife'' Accident |author=Silverman, Stephen M. |publisher=''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' |date=7 September 2012 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Chenoweth">{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2012/07/11/kristin-chenoweth-hospitalized-the-good-wife/ |title=Kristin Chenoweth Hospitalized After Accident on 'Good Wife' [PHOTOS] |publisher=[[TMZ]] |date=12 July 2012 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> * ''[[The Hobbit (film series)|The Hobbit]]'' (2012–2014). As many as 27 animals were killed during the production of this film, mainly from the hazardous conditions of the farm they were housed in. Several goats and sheep fell into a sinkhole under the farm. One horse was [[Hobble (device)|hobbled]] and left on the ground for three hours. Another horse was killed after falling off an embankment of an overcrowded paddock. One horse had the skin and muscles of her leg torn off by wire fencing.
